# Cristiano Ronaldo

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

Portuguese footballer

For the Brazilian footballer, see [Ronaldo (Brazilian
footballer)](/wiki/Ronaldo_\(Brazilian_footballer\) "Ronaldo \(Brazilian
footballer\)").

This name uses [Portuguese naming customs](/wiki/Portuguese_name "Portuguese
name"). The first or maternal [family name](/wiki/Surname "Surname") is
_Santos_ and the second or paternal family name is _Aveiro_.

**Cristiano Ronaldo dos Santos Aveiro** [GOIH](/wiki/Order_of_Prince_Henry
"Order of Prince Henry") [ComM](/wiki/Order_of_Merit_\(Portugal\) "Order of
Merit \(Portugal\)") (European Portuguese: [[kɾiʃˈtjɐnu
ʁoˈnaɫdu]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Portuguese "Help:IPA/Portuguese"); born 5 February
1985) is a Portuguese professional [footballer](/wiki/Association_football
"Association football") who plays as a
[forward](/wiki/Forward_\(association_football\) "Forward \(association
football\)") for Italian club [Juventus](/wiki/Juventus_F.C. "Juventus F.C.")
and the [Portugal national team](/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team
"Portugal national football team"). Often considered the best player in the
world and regarded by many as one of the [greatest players of all
time](/wiki/List_of_association_football_players_considered_the_greatest_of_all_time
"List of association football players considered the greatest of all
time"),[4][5] Ronaldo has a record-tying five [Ballon
d'Or](/wiki/Ballon_d%27Or "Ballon d'Or") awards,[note 2] the most for a
European player, and is the first player to win four [European Golden
Shoes](/wiki/European_Golden_Shoe "European Golden Shoe"). He has won [26
trophies in his
career](/wiki/List_of_career_achievements_by_Cristiano_Ronaldo#Club "List of
career achievements by Cristiano Ronaldo"), including five league titles, five
[UEFA Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League")
titles and one [UEFA European Championship](/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship
"UEFA European Championship"). A prolific goalscorer, Ronaldo holds the
records for most official goals scored in Europe's top-five leagues (395), the
UEFA Champions League (120), the UEFA European Championship (9), as well as
those for most assists in the UEFA Champions League (34) and the UEFA European
Championship (6). He has scored over [670 senior career
goals](/wiki/List_of_men%27s_footballers_with_500_or_more_goals "List of men's
footballers with 500 or more goals") for club and country.

Born and raised on the Portuguese island of [Madeira](/wiki/Madeira
"Madeira"), Ronaldo was diagnosed with a [racing heart](/wiki/Tachycardia
"Tachycardia") at age 15. He underwent an operation to treat his condition,
and began his senior club career playing for [Sporting CP](/wiki/Sporting_CP
"Sporting CP"), before signing with [Manchester
United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United F.C.") at age 18 in
2003. After winning his first trophy, the [FA Cup](/wiki/FA_Cup "FA Cup"),
during his first season in England, he helped United win three successive
[Premier League](/wiki/Premier_League "Premier League") titles, a UEFA
Champions League title, and a [FIFA Club World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Club_World_Cup
"FIFA Club World Cup"). By age 22, he had received Ballon d'Or and [FIFA World
Player of the Year](/wiki/FIFA_World_Player_of_the_Year "FIFA World Player of
the Year") nominations and at age 23, he won his first Ballon d'Or and FIFA
World Player of the Year awards. In 2009, Ronaldo was the subject of the [most
expensive association football
transfer](/wiki/Most_expensive_association_football_transfer "Most expensive
association football transfer")[note 3] when he moved from Manchester United
to [Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_C.F. "Real Madrid C.F.") in a
[transfer](/wiki/Transfer_\(association_football\) "Transfer \(association
football\)") worth €94 million (£80 million).

In Madrid, Ronaldo won 15 trophies, including two [La Liga](/wiki/La_Liga "La
Liga") titles, two [Copas del Rey](/wiki/Copas_del_Rey "Copas del Rey"), four
UEFA Champions League titles, two [UEFA Super Cups](/wiki/UEFA_Super_Cup "UEFA
Super Cup"), and three FIFA Club World Cups. [Real Madrid's all-time top
goalscorer](/wiki/Real_Madrid%27s_all-time_leading_goalscorer "Real Madrid's
all-time leading goalscorer"), Ronaldo scored [a record 34 La Liga hat-
tricks](/wiki/List_of_La_Liga_hat-tricks#Multiple_hat-tricks "List of La Liga
hat-tricks"), including a record-tying eight hat-tricks in the
[2014–15](/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_La_Liga "2014–15 La Liga") season[note 4] and
is the only player to reach 30 goals in six consecutive La Liga seasons. After
joining Madrid, Ronaldo finished runner-up for the Ballon d'Or three times,
behind [Lionel Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi"), his perceived
[career rival](/wiki/Messi%E2%80%93Ronaldo_rivalry "Messi–Ronaldo rivalry"),
before winning back-to-back Ballons d'Or in
[2013](/wiki/2013_FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or "2013 FIFA Ballon d'Or") and
[2014](/wiki/2014_FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or "2014 FIFA Ballon d'Or"). After winning
the [2016](/wiki/2016_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2016 UEFA Champions League
Final") and [2017](/wiki/2017_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2017 UEFA Champions
League Final") Champions Leagues, Ronaldo secured back-to-back Ballons d'Or
again in [2016](/wiki/2016_Ballon_d%27Or "2016 Ballon d'Or") and
[2017](/wiki/2017_Ballon_d%27Or "2017 Ballon d'Or"). A historic [third
consecutive Champions League](/wiki/2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2018
UEFA Champions League Final") followed, making Ronaldo the first player to win
the trophy five times.[6] In 2018, he signed for Juventus in a transfer worth
€100 million, the highest fee ever paid for a player over 30 years old, and
the highest ever paid by an Italian club.

A Portuguese international, Ronaldo was named the best Portuguese player of
all time by the [Portuguese Football
Federation](/wiki/Portuguese_Football_Federation "Portuguese Football
Federation") in 2015. He made his senior debut for Portugal in 2003 at age 18,
and has since had [over 150
caps](/wiki/List_of_footballers_with_100_or_more_caps "List of footballers
with 100 or more caps"), including appearing and scoring in eight major
tournaments, becoming [Portugal's most capped
player](/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team#Most_capped_players "Portugal
national football team") and [his country's all-time top
goalscorer](/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team#Top_goalscorers "Portugal
national football team"). He scored his first international goal at [Euro
2004](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2004 "UEFA Euro 2004") and helped Portugal reach [the
final](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2004_Final "UEFA Euro 2004 Final"). He [took over full
captaincy](/wiki/List_of_Portugal_national_football_team_captains "List of
Portugal national football team captains") in July 2008, leading Portugal to
their first-ever triumph in a major tournament by winning [Euro
2016](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016 "UEFA Euro 2016"), and received the [Silver
Boot](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016#Awards "UEFA Euro 2016") as the second-highest
goalscorer of the tournament, before becoming the highest European
[international goalscorer of all-
time](/wiki/List_of_men%27s_footballers_with_50_or_more_international_goals
"List of men's footballers with 50 or more international goals").[7] One of
the most marketable athletes in the world, he was ranked the [world's highest-
paid athlete](/wiki/Forbes%27_list_of_the_world%27s_highest-paid_athletes
"Forbes' list of the world's highest-paid athletes") by _[Forbes](/wiki/Forbes
"Forbes")_ in 2016 and 2017, as well as the world's most famous athlete by
[ESPN](/wiki/ESPN "ESPN") in 2016, 2017 and 2018.

## Early life

Cristiano Ronaldo dos Santos Aveiro was born in [São
Pedro](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Pedro_\(Funchal\) "São Pedro \(Funchal\)"),
[Funchal](/wiki/Funchal "Funchal"), Portugal and grew up in the Funchal parish
of [Santo António](/wiki/Santo_Ant%C3%B3nio_\(Funchal\) "Santo António
\(Funchal\)"),[8][9] as the youngest child of Maria Dolores dos Santos Aveiro,
a cook, and José Dinis Aveiro, a municipal gardener and a part-time [kit
man](/wiki/Equipment_manager "Equipment manager").[10] His second given name,
"Ronaldo", was chosen after then-U.S. president [Ronald
Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan").[11] He has one older brother,
Hugo, and two older sisters, Elma and Liliana Cátia.[2] His great-grandmother
on his father's side, Isabel da Piedade, was from [São Vicente, Cape
Verde](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Vicente,_Cape_Verde "São Vicente, Cape Verde").[12]
Ronaldo grew up in a Catholic and impoverished home, sharing a room with his
brother and sisters.[13]

As a child, Ronaldo played for amateur team [Andorinha](/wiki/CF_Andorinha "CF
Andorinha") from 1992 to 1995,[14] where his father was the kit man,[15] and
later spent two years with [Nacional](/wiki/C.D._Nacional "C.D. Nacional"). In
1997, aged 12, he went on a three-day trial with [Sporting
CP](/wiki/Sporting_CP "Sporting CP"), who signed him for a fee of
£1,500.[16][17] He subsequently moved from Madeira to
[Alcochete](/wiki/Alcochete "Alcochete"), near [Lisbon](/wiki/Lisbon
"Lisbon"), to join Sporting's other youth players at [the club's football
academy](/wiki/Sporting_CP_Youth_Academy "Sporting CP Youth Academy").[16] By
age 14, Ronaldo believed he had the ability to play semi-professionally, and
agreed with his mother to cease his education in order to focus entirely on
football.[18] While popular with other students at school, he had been
expelled after throwing a chair at his teacher, who he said had "disrespected"
him.[18] However, one year later, he was diagnosed with a [racing
heart](/wiki/Tachycardia "Tachycardia"), a condition that could have forced
him to give up playing football.[19] Ronaldo underwent heart surgery where a
laser was used to cauterise multiple [cardiac
pathways](/wiki/Electrical_conduction_system_of_the_heart "Electrical
conduction system of the heart"), altering his [resting heart
rate](/wiki/Heart_rate "Heart rate").[20] He was discharged from the hospital
hours after the procedure and resumed training a few days later.[21]

## Club career

### Sporting CP

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/C.Ronaldo_at_Museum_Mundo_Sporting.JPG/220px-C.Ronaldo_at_Museum_Mundo_Sporting.JPG)](/wiki/File:C.Ronaldo_at_Museum_Mundo_Sporting.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:C.Ronaldo_at_Museum_Mundo_Sporting.JPG "Powiększ")

Ronaldo memorabilia at Sporting CP's museum

At age 16, Ronaldo was promoted from Sporting's youth team by first-team
manager [László Bölöni](/wiki/L%C3%A1szl%C3%B3_B%C3%B6l%C3%B6ni "László
Bölöni"), who was impressed with his dribbling.[22] He subsequently became the
first player to play for the club's under-16, under-17 and under-18 teams, the
B team, and the first team, all within a single season.[16] A year later, on 7
October 2002, Ronaldo made his debut in the [Primeira
Liga](/wiki/Primeira_Liga "Primeira Liga"), against
[Moreirense](/wiki/Moreirense_F.C. "Moreirense F.C."), and scored two goals in
their 3–0 win.[23] Over the course of the [2002–03
season](/wiki/2002%E2%80%9303_Primeira_Liga "2002–03 Primeira Liga"), his
representatives suggested the player to [Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool_F.C.
"Liverpool F.C.") manager [Gérard Houllier](/wiki/G%C3%A9rard_Houllier "Gérard
Houllier") and [Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona") president [Joan
Laporta](/wiki/Joan_Laporta "Joan Laporta").[24] Manager [Arsène
Wenger](/wiki/Ars%C3%A8ne_Wenger "Arsène Wenger"), who was interested in
signing the winger, met with him at [Arsenal](/wiki/Arsenal_F.C. "Arsenal
F.C.")'s grounds in November to discuss a possible transfer.[25]

[Manchester United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United F.C.")
manager [Alex Ferguson](/wiki/Alex_Ferguson "Alex Ferguson"), however,
determined to acquire Ronaldo on a permanent move urgently, after Sporting
defeated United 3–1 at the inauguration of the [Estádio José
Alvalade](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_Jos%C3%A9_Alvalade "Estádio José Alvalade") in
August 2003. Initially, United had just planned to sign Ronaldo and then loan
him back to Sporting for a year.[26] Having impressed the Manchester United
players, however, they urged Ferguson to sign him. After the game, Ferguson
agreed to pay Sporting £12.24 million[26] for what he considered to be "one of
the most exciting young players" he had ever seen.[27] A decade after his
departure from the club, in April 2013, Sporting honoured Ronaldo by selecting
him to become their 100,000th member.[28]

### Manchester United

#### 2003–07: Development and breakthrough

Ronaldo became Manchester United's first-ever Portuguese player when he signed
before the [2003–04 season](/wiki/2003%E2%80%9304_FA_Premier_League "2003–04
FA Premier League").[29] His transfer fee of £12.24 million made him, at the
time, the most expensive teenager in English football history.[30] Although he
requested the number 28, his number at Sporting, he received the [number 7
shirt](/wiki/Squad_number_\(association_football\) "Squad number \(association
football\)"), which had previously been worn by such United players as [George
Best](/wiki/George_Best "George Best"), [Eric Cantona](/wiki/Eric_Cantona
"Eric Cantona") and [David Beckham](/wiki/David_Beckham "David
Beckham").[31][32] Wearing the number 7 became an extra source of motivation
for Ronaldo.[32] A key element in his development during his time in England
proved to be his manager, Alex Ferguson, of whom he later said, "He's been my
father in sport, one of the most important and influential factors in my
career."[33]

Ronaldo made his debut in the [Premier League](/wiki/Premier_League "Premier
League") in a 4–0 home victory over [Bolton
Wanderers](/wiki/Bolton_Wanderers_F.C. "Bolton Wanderers F.C.") on 16 August
2003, receiving a standing ovation when he came on as a 60th-minute substitute
for [Nicky Butt](/wiki/Nicky_Butt "Nicky Butt").[34] His performance earned
praise from George Best, who hailed it as "undoubtedly the most exciting
debut" he had ever seen.[35] Ronaldo scored his first goal for Manchester
United with a free-kick in a 3–0 win over [Portsmouth](/wiki/Portsmouth_F.C.
"Portsmouth F.C.") on 1 November.[36] Three other league goals followed in the
second half of the campaign,[37] the last of which came against [Aston
Villa](/wiki/Aston_Villa_F.C. "Aston Villa F.C.") on the final day of the
season, a match in which he also received his first [red
card](/wiki/Penalty_card "Penalty card").[38] Ronaldo ended his first season
in English football by scoring the opening goal in United's 3–0 victory over
[Millwall](/wiki/Millwall_F.C. "Millwall F.C.") in the [FA Cup
final](/wiki/2004_FA_Cup_Final "2004 FA Cup Final"), earning his first
trophy.[39]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Ronaldo_-
_Manchester_United_vs_Chelsea.jpg/220px-Ronaldo_-
_Manchester_United_vs_Chelsea.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ronaldo_-
_Manchester_United_vs_Chelsea.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ronaldo_-_Manchester_United_vs_Chelsea.jpg "Powiększ")

Ronaldo playing against [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C. "Chelsea F.C.") in the
Premier League during his third season in England

At the start of 2005, Ronaldo played two of his best matches of the [2004–05
season](/wiki/2004%E2%80%9305_FA_Premier_League "2004–05 FA Premier League"),
producing a goal and an assist against Aston Villa and scoring twice against
[rivals](/wiki/Arsenal_F.C.%E2%80%93Manchester_United_F.C._rivalry "Arsenal
F.C.–Manchester United F.C. rivalry") Arsenal.[40][41] He played the full 120
minutes of the decisive match against Arsenal in the [FA Cup
final](/wiki/2005_FA_Cup_Final "2005 FA Cup Final"), which ended in a goalless
draw, and scored his attempt in the lost [penalty
shootout](/wiki/Penalty_shootout "Penalty shootout").[42] He scored Manchester
United's 1000th Premier League goal on 29 October, their only strike in a 4–1
loss to [Middlesbrough](/wiki/Middlesbrough_F.C. "Middlesbrough F.C.").[43]
Midway through the season, in November, he signed a new contract which
extended his previous deal by two years to 2010.[44] Ronaldo won his second
trophy in English football, the [Football League
Cup](/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_Football_League_Cup "2005–06 Football League Cup"),
after scoring the third goal in United's 4–0 final victory over [Wigan
Athletic](/wiki/Wigan_Athletic_F.C. "Wigan Athletic F.C.").[45]

During his third season in England, Ronaldo was involved in several incidents.
He had a one-match ban imposed on him by [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") for a
"[one-fingered gesture](/wiki/The_finger "The finger")" towards
[Benfica](/wiki/S.L._Benfica "S.L. Benfica") fans,[46] and was sent off in the
[Manchester derby](/wiki/Manchester_derby "Manchester derby")—a 3–1 defeat—for
kicking [Manchester City](/wiki/Manchester_City_F.C. "Manchester City F.C.")'s
former United player [Andy Cole](/wiki/Andy_Cole "Andy Cole").[47] Ronaldo
clashed with a teammate, striker [Ruud van
Nistelrooy](/wiki/Ruud_van_Nistelrooy "Ruud van Nistelrooy"), who took offence
at the winger's showboating style of play.[48] Following the [2006 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup"), in which he was
involved in an incident where club teammate [Wayne Rooney](/wiki/Wayne_Rooney
"Wayne Rooney") was sent off,[49] Ronaldo publicly asked for a transfer,
lamenting the lack of support he felt he had received from the club over the
incident.[50] United, however, denied the possibility of him leaving the
club.[51]

Although his World Cup altercation with Rooney resulted in Ronaldo being booed
throughout the [2006–07 season](/wiki/2006%E2%80%9307_FA_Premier_League
"2006–07 FA Premier League"),[52] it proved to be his breakout year, as he
broke the 20-goal barrier for the first time and won his first [Premier League
title](/wiki/List_of_English_football_champions "List of English football
champions"). An important factor in this success was his one-to-one training
by first-team coach [René Meulensteen](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Meulensteen "René
Meulensteen"), who taught him to make himself more unpredictable, improve his
teamwork, call for the ball, and capitalise on goalscoring opportunities
rather than waiting for the chance to score the aesthetically pleasing goals
for which he was already known.[53] He scored three consecutive braces at the
end of December, against Aston Villa—a victory which put United on top of the
league—Wigan Athletic, and [Reading](/wiki/Reading_F.C. "Reading
F.C.").[54][55][56] Ronaldo was named the [Premier League Player of the
Month](/wiki/FA_Premier_League_Player_of_the_Month "FA Premier League Player
of the Month") in November and December, becoming only the third player to
receive consecutive honours.[57][58]

#### 2007–09: Collective and individual success

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Cristiano_Ronaldo.jpg/220px-
Cristiano_Ronaldo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo.jpg "Powiększ")

Ronaldo during the 2006–07 season

At the quarter-final stage of the [2006–07 UEFA Champions
League](/wiki/2006%E2%80%9307_UEFA_Champions_League "2006–07 UEFA Champions
League"), Ronaldo scored his first-ever goals in the competition, finding the
net twice in a 7–1 victory over [Roma](/wiki/A.S._Roma "A.S. Roma").[59] He
subsequently scored four minutes into the first semi-final leg against
[Milan](/wiki/A.C._Milan "A.C. Milan"), which ended in a 3–2 win,[60] but was
[marked](/wiki/Marking_\(association_football\) "Marking \(association
football\)") out of the second leg as United lost 3–0 at the [San
Siro](/wiki/San_Siro "San Siro").[61] He also helped United reach the [FA Cup
final](/wiki/2007_FA_Cup_Final "2007 FA Cup Final"), but the decisive match
against [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C. "Chelsea F.C.") ended in a 1–0
defeat.[62] Ronaldo scored the only goal in the Manchester derby on 5 May
2007—his 50th goal for the club—as Manchester United claimed their first
Premier League title in four years.[63] As a result of his performances, he
amassed a host of personal awards for the season. He won the [Professional
Footballers' Association](/wiki/Professional_Footballers%27_Association
"Professional Footballers' Association")'s [Player's
Player](/wiki/PFA_Players%27_Player_of_the_Year "PFA Players' Player of the
Year"), [Fans' Player](/wiki/PFA_Fans%27_Player_of_the_Year "PFA Fans' Player
of the Year"), and [Young Player of the
Year](/wiki/PFA_Young_Player_of_the_Year "PFA Young Player of the Year")
awards, as well as the [Football Writers'
Association](/wiki/Football_Writers%27_Association "Football Writers'
Association")'s [Footballer of the Year](/wiki/FWA_Footballer_of_the_Year "FWA
Footballer of the Year") award,[64][65] becoming the first player to win all
four main PFA and FWA honours.[66] His club wages were concurrently upgraded
to £120,000 a week (£31 million total) as part of a five-year contract
extension with United.[67]

Ronaldo scored a total of 42 goals in all competitions during the [2007–08
season](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_FA_Premier_League "2007–08 FA Premier League"),
his most prolific campaign during his time in England. He missed three matches
after headbutting a [Portsmouth](/wiki/Portsmouth_F.C. "Portsmouth F.C.")
player at the start of the season, an experience he said taught him not to let
opponents provoke him.[68] At the end of 2007, Ronaldo was named runner-up to
[Kaká](/wiki/Kak%C3%A1 "Kaká") for the [Ballon d'Or](/wiki/Ballon_d%27Or
"Ballon d'Or"),[69] and came third, behind Kaká and [Lionel
Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi"), in the running for the [FIFA World
Player of the Year](/wiki/FIFA_World_Player_of_the_Year "FIFA World Player of
the Year") award.[70]

Ronaldo scored his first and only [hat-trick](/wiki/Hat-
trick_\(association_football\) "Hat-trick \(association football\)") for
Manchester United in a 6–0 win against [Newcastle
United](/wiki/Newcastle_United_F.C. "Newcastle United F.C.") on 12 January
2008, bringing United up to the top of the Premier League table.[71] A month
later, on 19 March, he captained United for the first time in a home win over
Bolton, and scored both goals of the match.[72] His second goal was his 33rd
of the campaign, which bettered George Best's total of 32 goals in the 1967–68
season, thus setting the club's new single-season record by a midfielder.[73]
His 31 league goals earned him the [Premier League Golden
Boot](/wiki/Premier_League_Golden_Boot "Premier League Golden Boot"),[74] as
well as the [European Golden Shoe](/wiki/European_Golden_Shoe "European Golden
Shoe"), which made him the first winger to win the latter award.[75]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/C_Ronaldo.jpg/170px-
C_Ronaldo.jpg)](/wiki/File:C_Ronaldo.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:C_Ronaldo.jpg "Powiększ")

Ronaldo taking a [direct free kick](/wiki/Direct_free_kick "Direct free kick")
against [Celtic](/wiki/Celtic_F.C. "Celtic F.C.") in the [2008–09 UEFA
Champions League](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_UEFA_Champions_League "2008–09 UEFA
Champions League")

In the knockout stage of the Champions League, Ronaldo scored the decisive
goal against [Lyon](/wiki/Olympique_Lyonnais "Olympique Lyonnais"), which
helped United advance to the quarter-finals 2–1 on aggregate,[76] and, while
playing as a striker, scored with a header in the 3–0 aggregate victory over
Roma.[77] United advanced to the
[final](/wiki/2008_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2008 UEFA Champions League
Final") against Chelsea in Moscow, where, despite his opening goal being
negated by an equaliser and his penalty being saved in the shoot-out,[78]
Manchester United emerged victorious.[79] As the [Champions League top
scorer](/wiki/List_of_European_Cup_and_UEFA_Champions_League_top_scorers "List
of European Cup and UEFA Champions League top scorers"), Ronaldo was named the
[UEFA Club Footballer of the Year](/wiki/UEFA_Club_Footballer_of_the_Year
"UEFA Club Footballer of the Year").[80] He additionally received the PFA
Players' Player of the Year and FWA Footballer of the Year awards for the
second consecutive season.[81][82]

As rumours circulated of Ronaldo's interest in moving to [Real
Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_C.F. "Real Madrid C.F."), United filed a tampering
complaint with governing body FIFA over Madrid's alleged pursuit of their
player, but they declined to take action.[83] FIFA president [Sepp
Blatter](/wiki/Sepp_Blatter "Sepp Blatter") asserted that the player should be
allowed to leave his club, describing the situation as "modern slavery".[84]
Despite Ronaldo publicly agreeing with Blatter,[85] he remained at United for
another year.[86] Ahead of the [2008–09
season](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_FA_Premier_League "2008–09 FA Premier League"),
on 7 July, he underwent ankle surgery,[87] which kept him out of action for 10
weeks.[88] Following his return, he scored his 100th goal in all competitions
for United with the first of two free kicks in a 5–0 win against [Stoke
City](/wiki/Stoke_City_F.C. "Stoke City F.C.") on 15 November,[89] which meant
he had now scored against all 19 opposition teams in the Premier League at the
time.[90] At the close of 2008, Ronaldo helped United win the [FIFA Club World
Cup](/wiki/2008_FIFA_Club_World_Cup "2008 FIFA Club World Cup") in Japan,[91]
assisting the [final](/wiki/2008_FIFA_Club_World_Cup_Final "2008 FIFA Club
World Cup Final")-winning goal against [Liga de Quito](/wiki/LDU_Quito "LDU
Quito") and winning the [Silver
Ball](/wiki/List_of_FIFA_Club_World_Cup_awards#Golden_Ball "List of FIFA Club
World Cup awards") in the process.[92][93] He subsequently became United's
first [Ballon d'Or](/wiki/2008_Ballon_d%27Or "2008 Ballon d'Or") winner since
George Best in 1968,[94] and the first Premier League player to be named the
[FIFA World Player of the Year](/wiki/2008_FIFA_World_Player_of_the_Year "2008
FIFA World Player of the Year").[95]

His match-winning goal in the second leg against [Porto](/wiki/FC_Porto "FC
Porto"), a 40-yard strike, earned him the inaugural [FIFA Puskás
Award](/wiki/FIFA_Pusk%C3%A1s_Award "FIFA Puskás Award"), presented by FIFA in
recognition of the best goal of the year;[96] he later called it the best goal
he had ever scored.[97] United advanced to the
[final](/wiki/2009_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2009 UEFA Champions League
Final") in Rome,[98] where he made little impact in United's 2–0 defeat to
Barcelona.[99] Ronaldo ended his time in England with nine trophies, as United
claimed their third successive Premier League title and a [Football League
Cup](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_Football_League_Cup "2008–09 Football League
Cup").[100][101] He finished the campaign with 26 goals in all competitions,
16 goals fewer than the previous season, in four more appearances.[102] His
final ever goal for Manchester United came on 10 May 2009 with a free kick in
the Manchester derby at [Old Trafford](/wiki/Old_Trafford "Old
Trafford").[103]

### Real Madrid

#### 2009–13: World record transfer and La Liga championship

Ahead of the [2009–10 season](/wiki/2009%E2%80%9310_La_Liga "2009–10 La
Liga"), Ronaldo joined Real Madrid for a [world record transfer
fee](/wiki/World_football_transfer_record "World football transfer record") at
the time, of £80 million (€94 million).[104] His contract, which ran until
2015, was worth €11 million per year and contained a €1 billion buy-out
clause.[105] At least 80,000 fans attended his presentation at the [Santiago
Bernabéu](/wiki/Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_Stadium "Santiago Bernabéu Stadium"),
surpassing the 25-year record of 75,000 fans who had welcomed [Diego
Maradona](/wiki/Diego_Maradona "Diego Maradona") at
[Napoli](/wiki/S.S.C._Napoli "S.S.C. Napoli").[106] Since club captain
[Raúl](/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_\(footballer\) "Raúl \(footballer\)") already wore the
number 7, the number Ronaldo wore at Manchester United,[107] Ronaldo received
the number 9 shirt,[108] which was presented to him by former Madrid player
[Alfredo Di Stéfano](/wiki/Alfredo_Di_St%C3%A9fano "Alfredo Di Stéfano").[109]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Cristiano_Ronaldo_Madrid.jpg/175px-
Cristiano_Ronaldo_Madrid.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_Madrid.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_Madrid.jpg "Powiększ")

As his usual number 7 was unavailable, Ronaldo wore number 9 during his first
season at Madrid. Following [Raúl](/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_\(footballer\) "Raúl
\(footballer\)")'s departure, Ronaldo was handed the number 7 shirt before the
[2010–11 season](/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_La_Liga "2010–11 La Liga").

Ronaldo made his debut in [La Liga](/wiki/La_Liga "La Liga") on 29 August
2009, against [Deportivo La Coruña](/wiki/Deportivo_de_La_Coru%C3%B1a
"Deportivo de La Coruña"), and scored from the penalty spot in Madrid's 3–2
home win.[110] He scored in each of his first four league fixtures with the
club, the first Madrid player to do so.[111] His first Champions League goals
for the club followed with two free kicks in the first group match against
[Zürich](/wiki/FC_Z%C3%BCrich "FC Zürich").[112] His strong start to the
season, however, was interrupted when he suffered an ankle injury in October
while on international duty, which kept him sidelined for seven
weeks.[113][114] A week after his return, he received his first red card in
Spain in a match against [Almería](/wiki/UD_Almer%C3%ADa "UD Almería").[115]
Midway through the season, Ronaldo placed second in the running for the
[Ballon d'Or](/wiki/2009_Ballon_d%27Or "2009 Ballon d'Or") and the [FIFA World
Player of the Year](/wiki/2009_FIFA_World_Player_of_the_Year "2009 FIFA World
Player of the Year") award, behind Lionel Messi of
[Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona"), Madrid's historic rivals. He
finished the campaign with 33 goals in all competitions, including a hat-trick
in a 4–1 win against [Mallorca](/wiki/RCD_Mallorca "RCD Mallorca") on 5 May
2010, his first in the Spanish competition.[116][117] His first season at Real
Madrid ended trophyless.[118]

Following Raúl's departure, Ronaldo was handed the number 7 shirt for Real
Madrid before the [2010–11 season](/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_La_Liga "2010–11 La
Liga").[107] His subsequent return to his Ballon d'Or-winning form was
epitomised when, for the first time in his career, he scored four goals in a
single match during a 6–1 rout against [Racing
Santander](/wiki/Racing_de_Santander "Racing de Santander") on 23
October.[119] His haul concluded a goalscoring run of six consecutive
matches—three in La Liga, one in the Champions League, and two for
Portugal—totalling 11 goals, the most he had scored in a single month. Ronaldo
subsequently scored further hat-tricks against [Athletic
Bilbao](/wiki/Athletic_Bilbao "Athletic Bilbao"), [Levante](/wiki/Levante_UD
"Levante UD"), [Villarreal](/wiki/Villarreal_CF "Villarreal CF"), and
[Málaga](/wiki/M%C3%A1laga_CF "Málaga CF").[120][121][122] Despite his
performance, he failed to make the podium for the inaugural [FIFA Ballon
d'Or](/wiki/FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or "FIFA Ballon d'Or") at the end of 2010.[123]

During a historical series of four _[Clásicos](/wiki/El_Cl%C3%A1sico "El
Clásico")_ against rivals Barcelona in April 2011, Ronaldo scored twice to
equal his personal record of 42 goals in all competitions in a single season.
Although he failed to find the net during Madrid's eventual elimination in the
Champions League semi-finals, he equalised from the penalty spot in the return
league game and scored the match-winning goal in the 103rd minute of the [Copa
del Rey final](/wiki/2011_Copa_del_Rey_Final "2011 Copa del Rey Final"),
winning his first trophy in Spain.[124][125] Over the next two weeks, Ronaldo
scored another four-goal haul against [Sevilla](/wiki/Sevilla_FC "Sevilla
FC"),[126] a hat-trick against [Getafe](/wiki/Getafe_CF "Getafe CF"),[127] and
a brace of free kicks against Villarreal, taking his league total to 38 goals,
which equalled the record for most goals scored in a season held by [Telmo
Zarra](/wiki/Telmo_Zarra "Telmo Zarra") and [Hugo
Sánchez](/wiki/Hugo_S%C3%A1nchez "Hugo Sánchez").[128] His two goals in the
last match of the season, against [Almería](/wiki/UD_Almer%C3%ADa "UD
Almería"), made him the first player in La Liga to score 40 goals.[129] In
addition to the [Pichichi Trophy](/wiki/Pichichi_Trophy "Pichichi Trophy"),
Ronaldo consequently won the European Golden Shoe for a second time, becoming
the first player to win the award in two different leagues.[130] He ended his
second season at Real Madrid with a total of 53 goals in all competitions.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Cristiano_Ajax.jpg/170px-
Cristiano_Ajax.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ajax.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ajax.jpg "Powiększ")

Ronaldo scored 46 league goals during the La Liga championship success in his
third season in Spain.

During the following campaign, the [2011–12
season](/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_La_Liga "2011–12 La Liga"), Ronaldo surpassed
his previous goalscoring feats to achieve a new personal best of 60 goals
across all competitions.[131] His 100th goal for Real Madrid came at [Camp
Nou](/wiki/Camp_Nou "Camp Nou") in the [Supercopa de
España](/wiki/2011_Supercopa_de_Espa%C3%B1a "2011 Supercopa de España"),
though Barcelona claimed the trophy 5–4 on aggregate.[132] He regained a place
on the [FIFA Ballon d'Or](/wiki/2011_FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or "2011 FIFA Ballon
d'Or") podium, as runner-up to Messi, after scoring hat-tricks against [Real
Zaragoza](/wiki/Real_Zaragoza "Real Zaragoza"), [Rayo
Vallecano](/wiki/Rayo_Vallecano "Rayo Vallecano"), Málaga,
[Osasuna](/wiki/CA_Osasuna "CA Osasuna"), and Sevilla, the last of which put
Madrid on top of the league by the season's midway point.[133][134][135]
Despite two goals from Ronaldo, Madrid were subsequently defeated by Barcelona
4–3 on aggregrate in the quarter-finals of the Copa del Rey. He again scored
twice, including a penalty, in the Champions League semi-finals against
[Bayern Munich](/wiki/FC_Bayern_Munich "FC Bayern Munich"), resulting in a 3–3
draw, but his penalty kick in the shootout was saved by [Manuel
Neuer](/wiki/Manuel_Neuer "Manuel Neuer"), leading to Madrid's
elimination.[136]

Ronaldo found greater team success in the league, as he helped Real Madrid win
their first [La Liga title](/wiki/List_of_Spanish_football_champions "List of
Spanish football champions") in four years, with a record 100 points.
Following a hat-trick against Levante, further increasing Madrid's lead over
Barcelona,[137] he scored his 100th league goal for Madrid in a 5–1 win over
[Real Sociedad](/wiki/Real_Sociedad "Real Sociedad") on 24 March 2012, a
milestone he reached in just 92 matches across three seasons, breaking the
previous club record held by [Ferenc Puskás](/wiki/Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s "Ferenc
Puskás").[138] Another hat-trick in the [Madrid derby](/wiki/Madrid_derby
"Madrid derby") against [Atlético Madrid](/wiki/Atl%C3%A9tico_Madrid "Atlético
Madrid") brought his total to 40 league goals, equalling his record of the
previous season.[139] His final league goal of the campaign, against Mallorca,
took his total to 46 goals, four short of the new record set by Messi,[140]
and earned him the distinction of being the first player to score against all
19 opposition teams in a single season in La Liga.[141]

Ronaldo began the [2012–13 season](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_La_Liga "2012–13 La
Liga") by lifting the [Supercopa de
España](/wiki/2012_Supercopa_de_Espa%C3%B1a "2012 Supercopa de España"), his
third trophy in Spain. With a goal in each leg by the Portuguese, Madrid won
the Spanish Super Cup on away goals following a 4–4 aggregate draw against
Barcelona.[142] Although Ronaldo publicly commented that he was unhappy with a
"professional issue" within the club, prompted by his refusal to celebrate his
150th goal for Madrid,[143] his goalscoring rate did not suffer. After netting
a hat-trick, including two penalties, against Deportivo La Coruña, he scored
his first [hat-trick in the Champions
League](/wiki/List_of_UEFA_Champions_League_hat-tricks "List of UEFA Champions
League hat-tricks") in a 4–1 victory over [Ajax](/wiki/AFC_Ajax "AFC
Ajax").[144] Four days later, he became the first player to score in six
successive _Clásicos_ when he hit a brace in a 2–2 draw at Camp Nou.[145] His
performances in 2012 again saw Ronaldo voted second in the running for the
[FIFA Ballon d'Or](/wiki/2012_FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or "2012 FIFA Ballon d'Or"),
finishing runner-up to four-time winner Messi.[146]

#### 2013–15: Consecutive FIFA Ballon d'Or wins and _La Décima_

Following the 2012–13 winter break, Ronaldo captained Real Madrid for the
first time in an official match, scoring a brace to lift 10-man Madrid to a
4–3 victory over Real Sociedad on 6 January.[147] He subsequently became the
first non-Spanish player in 60 years to captain Madrid in _El Clásico_ on 30
January, a match which also marked his 500th club appearance.[148] Three days
prior, he had scored his 300th club goal as part of a perfect hat-trick
against Getafe.[149] Following hat-tricks against Celta Vigo and
Sevilla,[150][151] he scored his 200th goal for Real Madrid on 8 May in a 6–2
win against Málaga, reaching the landmark in 197 games.[152] He helped Madrid
reach the [Copa del Rey final](/wiki/2013_Copa_del_Rey_Final "2013 Copa del
Rey Final") by scoring a brace in _El Clásico_ , which marked the sixth
successive match at Camp Nou in which he had scored,[153] a Real Madrid
record.[142] In the final, he headed the opening goal of an eventual 2–1
defeat to Atlético Madrid,[154] but was shown a straight red card in the 114th
minute for violent conduct.[155] Real Madrid also failed to defend their La
Liga title, finishing runners up to Barcelona.

In the first knockout round of the Champions League, Ronaldo faced his former
club Manchester United for the first time. After scoring the equaliser in a
1–1 draw at the Santiago Bernabéu,[156] he scored the match-winning goal in a
2–1 victory at Old Trafford, his first return to his former home ground.[157]
Ronaldo scored three goals in Madrid's 5–3 aggregate victory over
[Galatasaray](/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K._\(football\) "Galatasaray S.K.
\(football\)") to see them advance to the semi-finals,[158][159] He scored
Madrid's only goal in the 4–1 away defeat to [Borussia
Dortmund](/wiki/Borussia_Dortmund "Borussia Dortmund"),[160] but failed to
increase his side's 2–0 victory in the second leg, as they were eliminated at
the semi-final stage for the third consecutive year.[161] Ronaldo had scored
12 goals, finishing as the Champions League top goalscorer for a second time
in his career. Accounting for all competitions, he ended the season with a
total of 55 goals.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/CR_derbi_2013_cropped.png/170px-
CR_derbi_2013_cropped.png)](/wiki/File:CR_derbi_2013_cropped.png)

[](/wiki/File:CR_derbi_2013_cropped.png "Powiększ")

Ronaldo scored a record 17 goals during the 2013–14 _La Décima_ campaign.

Real Madrid's failure to win major silverware and reports of division among
the players prompted speculation regarding Ronaldo's future at the
club.[162][163] At the start of the [2013–14
season](/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_La_Liga "2013–14 La Liga"), however, he signed a
new contract that extended his stay by three years to 2018, with a salary of
€17 million net, making him briefly the highest-paid player in football.[164]
He was joined at the club by winger [Gareth Bale](/wiki/Gareth_Bale "Gareth
Bale"), whose world record transfer fee of €100 million surpassed the fee
Madrid had paid for Ronaldo four years prior.[165] Together with striker
[Karim Benzema](/wiki/Karim_Benzema "Karim Benzema"), they formed an attacking
trio popularly dubbed "BBC", an acronym of Bale, Benzema, and Cristiano, and a
play off the [name](/wiki/BBC "BBC") of the [public service
broadcaster](/wiki/Public_service_broadcaster "Public service
broadcaster").[166] After enjoying a strong goalscoring run during the first
half of the campaign, Ronaldo suggested that he was in the best form of his
career.[167] By late November, he had scored 32 goals from 22 matches played
for both club and country, including hat-tricks against Galatasaray, Sevilla,
Real Sociedad, [Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_national_football_team "Northern Ireland
national football team"), and [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden_national_football_team
"Sweden national football team").[168][169][170][171][172] He ended 2013 with
a total of 69 goals in 59 appearances, his highest year-end goal tally.[173]
His efforts earned him the [FIFA Ballon d'Or](/wiki/2013_FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or
"2013 FIFA Ballon d'Or"), an amalgamation of the Ballon d'Or and the FIFA
World Player of the Year award, for the first time in his career.

Concurrently with his individual achievements, Ronaldo enjoyed his greatest
team success in Spain to date, as he helped Real Madrid win _La Décima_ ,
their tenth European Cup. In the knockout phase of the competition, he scored
a brace in each leg of a 9–2 aggregate win against [Schalke
04](/wiki/FC_Schalke_04 "FC Schalke 04"),[174] helping Madrid advance to the
quarter-finals. His goal in a 3–0 home win over Borussia Dortmund—his 100th
Champions League match—took his total for the season to 14 goals, equalling
the record Messi had set two years before.[175] After hitting a brace in a 4–0
defeat of Bayern Munich at the [Allianz Arena](/wiki/Allianz_Arena "Allianz
Arena"),[176] he scored from the penalty spot in the 120th minute of the 4–1
final victory over Atlético Madrid, becoming the first player to score in two
European Cup finals for two different winning teams.[177] His overall
performance in the final was subdued as a result of [patellar
tendinitis](/wiki/Patellar_tendinitis "Patellar tendinitis") and related
hamstring problems, which had plagued him in the last months of the campaign.
Ronaldo played the final against medical advice, later commenting: "In your
life you do not win without sacrifices and you must take risks."[178] As the
Champions League top goalscorer for the third time, with a record 17
goals,[179][180] he was named the [UEFA Best Player in
Europe](/wiki/UEFA_Best_Player_in_Europe "UEFA Best Player in Europe").[181]

In the Copa del Rey, Ronaldo helped Madrid reach the
[final](/wiki/2014_Copa_del_Rey_Final "2014 Copa del Rey Final") by scoring a
brace of penalties against Atlético Madrid at the [Vicente
Calderón](/wiki/Vicente_Calder%C3%B3n_Stadium "Vicente Calderón
Stadium"),[182] the first of which meant he had now scored in every single
minute of a 90-minute football match.[183] His continued issues with his knee
and thigh caused him to miss the final,[178][184] where Real Madrid defeated
Barcelona 2–1 to claim the trophy.[185] While Madrid were less successful in
La Liga, finishing third, Ronaldo was unmatched as a goalscorer. He scored 31
goals in 30 league games, which earned him the Pichichi and the European
Golden Shoe, receiving the latter award jointly with Liverpool striker [Luis
Suárez](/wiki/Luis_Su%C3%A1rez "Luis Suárez").[186] Among his haul was his
400th career goal, in 653 appearances for club and country, which came with a
brace against Celta Vigo on 6 January; he dedicated his goals to compatriot
[Eusébio](/wiki/Eus%C3%A9bio "Eusébio"), who had died two days before.[187] A
last-minute, backheeled volley scored against Valencia on 4 May—his 50th goal
in all competitions—was recognised as the best goal of the season by the [Liga
de Fútbol Profesional](/wiki/Liga_de_F%C3%BAtbol_Profesional "Liga de Fútbol
Profesional"),[188] which additionally named Ronaldo the [Best Player in La
Liga](/wiki/LFP_Awards "LFP Awards").[189]

During the next campaign, the [2014–15 season](/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_La_Liga
"2014–15 La Liga"), Ronaldo set a new personal best of 61 goals in all
competitions, starting with both goals in Real Madrid's 2–0 victory over
Sevilla in the [UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/2014_UEFA_Super_Cup "2014 UEFA Super
Cup").[190][191] He subsequently achieved his best-ever goalscoring start to a
league campaign, with a record 15 goals in the first eight rounds of La Liga,
including a four-goal haul against [Elche](/wiki/Elche_CF "Elche CF") and hat-
tricks against Deportivo La Coruña and Athletic Bilbao.[192][193][194][195]
His record 23rd hat-trick in La Liga, scored against Celta Vigo on 6 December,
made him the fastest player to reach 200 goals in the Spanish league, as he
reached the milestone in only his 178th game.[195][196] After lifting the
[FIFA Club World Cup](/wiki/2014_FIFA_Club_World_Cup "2014 FIFA Club World
Cup") with Madrid in Morocco,[197] again winning the Silver Ball,[198][199]
Ronaldo received a second successive [FIFA Ballon
d'Or](/wiki/2014_FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or "2014 FIFA Ballon d'Or"),[200] joining
[Johan Cruyff](/wiki/Johan_Cruyff "Johan Cruyff"), [Michel
Platini](/wiki/Michel_Platini "Michel Platini"), and [Marco van
Basten](/wiki/Marco_van_Basten "Marco van Basten") as a three-time Ballon d'Or
winner.[201]

#### 2015–17: All-time Real Madrid top scorer and _La Undécima_

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Ronaldo_vs._FC_Schalke_04_%2816854146922%29.jpg/170px-
Ronaldo_vs._FC_Schalke_04_%2816854146922%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ronaldo_vs._FC_Schalke_04_\(16854146922\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ronaldo_vs._FC_Schalke_04_\(16854146922\).jpg "Powiększ")

Ronaldo scored a personal best of 61 goals in all competitions during the
2014–15 season.

Following the winter break, Ronaldo's form faltered, concurrently with a
decline in performance by his team.[202] A 2–1 defeat against Valencia in the
first match of 2015, despite his opening goal, ended Real Madrid's Spanish
record winning streak of 22 matches in all competitions.[203] Their season
continued unsuccessfully as they failed to win a major trophy, earning a
second-place league finish and a semi-final exit in Europe.[204] In the latter
competition, Ronaldo extended his run of scoring away to a record 12 matches
with his strike in a 2–0 win against Schalke 04,[205] before hitting a brace
in the 3–4 return defeat that allowed Madrid to progress to the quarter-
finals.[206] He then scored both of his side's goals in the semi-finals
against [Juventus](/wiki/Juventus_F.C. "Juventus F.C."), where Madrid were
eliminated 2–3 on aggregate.[207] With 10 goals, he finished the campaign as
top scorer for a third consecutive season, alongside Messi and
[Neymar](/wiki/Neymar "Neymar").[208]

In La Liga, where Madrid finished second, Ronaldo went on a prolific
goalscoring run towards the very end of the season. For the first time in his
career, he scored five goals in one game, including an eight-minute hat-trick,
in a 9–1 rout of [Granada](/wiki/Granada_CF "Granada CF") on 5 April.[209] His
300th goal for his club followed three days later in a 2–0 win against Rayo
Vallecano.[210] Subsequent hat-tricks against Sevilla,
[Espanyol](/wiki/RCD_Espanyol "RCD Espanyol"), and Getafe took his number of
hat-tricks for Real Madrid to 31, surpassing Di Stéfano's club record of 28
trebles.[190][211] As a result, Ronaldo finished the season with 48 goals, two
ahead of his total in the 2011–12 season, despite having missed two matches in
February for assaulting a [Córdoba](/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba_CF "Córdoba CF")
player.[212] In addition to a second consecutive Pichichi, he won the European
Golden Shoe for a record fourth time.[190][213]

At the start of his seventh season at Real Madrid, the [2015–16
campaign](/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_La_Liga "2015–16 La Liga"), Ronaldo became the
club's [all-time top
scorer](/wiki/List_of_Real_Madrid_C.F._records_and_statistics#Goalscorers
"List of Real Madrid C.F. records and statistics"), first in the league and
then in all competitions. His five-goal haul in a 6–0 away win over Espanyol
on 12 September took his tally in La Liga to 230 goals in 203 games,
surpassing the club's previous recordholder, Raúl.[214][215] A month later, on
17 October, he again surpassed Raúl when he scored the second goal in a 3–0
defeat of Levante at the Bernabéu to take his overall total for the club to
324 goals.[note 5] Ronaldo also became the [all-time top scorer in the
Champions
League](/wiki/List_of_European_Cup_and_UEFA_Champions_League_top_scorers "List
of European Cup and UEFA Champions League top scorers") with a hat-trick in
the first group match against [Shakhtar Donetsk](/wiki/FC_Shakhtar_Donetsk "FC
Shakhtar Donetsk"), having finished the previous season level with Messi on 77
goals.[218] A brace against Malmö FF, scoring in a 2–0 away win on 30
September, saw him reach the milestone of 500 career goals for both club and
country.[219][220] He subsequently became the first player to score double
figures in the competition's group stage, setting the record at 11 goals,
including another four-goal haul against Malmö.[221][222]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Cristiano_Ronaldo_ante_el_Celta_de_Vigo.JPG/220px-
Cristiano_Ronaldo_ante_el_Celta_de_Vigo.JPG)](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_ante_el_Celta_de_Vigo.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_ante_el_Celta_de_Vigo.JPG "Powiększ")

By March 2016, Ronaldo had scored 252 goals in 228 matches in La Liga to
become the competition's second-highest scorer.

Despite finishing runner-up to Messi for the [FIFA Ballon
d'Or](/wiki/2015_FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or "2015 FIFA Ballon d'Or"),[223] Ronaldo
received criticism for his form and performances against top teams, with 14 of
his goals coming against Espanyol and Malmö.[224][225] However, during the
second half of the season, his form gradually improved.[226] By scoring four
goals in a 7–1 home win over Celta de Vigo on 5 March 2016, Ronaldo arrived at
252 goals in La Liga to become the competition's second-highest scorer in
history behind Messi.[227] After netting the match-winning goal for 10-man
Madrid in a 2–1 _Clásico_ victory on 2 April,[228] he scored a hat-trick
against [VfL Wolfsburg](/wiki/VfL_Wolfsburg "VfL Wolfsburg") to send his club
into the Champions League semi-finals despite a 2–0 first-leg defeat.[229] The
treble took his tally in the competition to 16 goals, making him the top
scorer for the fourth consecutive season, and the fifth overall.[230]
Suffering apparent fitness issues, Ronaldo gave a poorly-received performance
in the [final](/wiki/2016_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2016 UEFA Champions
League Final") against Atlético Madrid, in a repeat of the 2014 final, though
his penalty in the subsequent shoot-out secured _La Undécima_ , Madrid's 11th
victory.[231][232] For the sixth successive year, he ended the season having
scored more than 50 goals across all competitions.[231] For his efforts during
the season, he received the [UEFA Best Player in Europe
Award](/wiki/UEFA_Best_Player_in_Europe_Award "UEFA Best Player in Europe
Award") for a second time.[233]

Ronaldo missed Real Madrid's first three matches of the [2016–17
season](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_La_Liga "2016–17 La Liga"), including the [2016
UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/2016_UEFA_Super_Cup "2016 UEFA Super Cup") against
Sevilla, as he continued to rehabilitate the knee injury he suffered against
[France](/wiki/France_national_football_team "France national football team")
in the final of [Euro 2016](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016_Final "UEFA Euro 2016
Final").[234] On 6 November, Ronaldo signed a new contract set to keep him
with Madrid until 2021.[235] On 19 November, he scored a hat-trick in a 3–0
away win against Atlético Madrid, making him the all-time top scorer in the
[Madrid derby](/wiki/Madrid_derby "Madrid derby") with 18 goals.[236][237] On
15 December, Ronaldo scored his 500th club career goal in the 2–0 victory over
[Club América](/wiki/Club_Am%C3%A9rica "Club América") in the semi-finals of
the [FIFA Club World Cup](/wiki/2016_FIFA_Club_World_Cup "2016 FIFA Club World
Cup").[238] He then scored a hat-trick in the 4–2 win over Japanese club
[Kashima Antlers](/wiki/Kashima_Antlers "Kashima Antlers") in the final.[239]
Ronaldo finished the tournament as top scorer with four goals and was also
named the best player of the tournament.[240] He won the [Ballon
d'Or](/wiki/2016_Ballon_d%27Or "2016 Ballon d'Or") for a fourth time and the
inaugural [Best FIFA Men's Player](/wiki/The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2016
"The Best FIFA Football Awards 2016"), a revival of the former [FIFA World
Player of the Year](/wiki/FIFA_World_Player_of_the_Year "FIFA World Player of
the Year"), largely owing to his success with Portugal in winning Euro
2016.[241][242]

#### 2017–18: A record fifth Champions League title and fifth Ballon d'Or

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Real_Madrid%2C_campe%C3%B3n_de_la_Champions_%2827309388231%29.jpg/220px-
Real_Madrid%2C_campe%C3%B3n_de_la_Champions_%2827309388231%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Real_Madrid,_campe%C3%B3n_de_la_Champions_\(27309388231\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Real_Madrid,_campe%C3%B3n_de_la_Champions_\(27309388231\).jpg
"Powiększ")

Ronaldo with then [President of the Community of
Madrid](/wiki/President_of_the_Community_of_Madrid "President of the Community
of Madrid"), [Cristina Cifuentes](/wiki/Cristina_Cifuentes "Cristina
Cifuentes"), during the title celebrations in Madrid

In Real Madrid's 3–2 away win against Villarreal on 27 February 2017, Ronaldo
overtook [Hugo Sánchez](/wiki/Hugo_S%C3%A1nchez "Hugo Sánchez") as the most
prolific penalty-kick scorer in La Liga history.[243][244] As a result of the
penalty scored by Ronaldo, Real Madrid reached its 5,900th goal in the history
of the league and became the first team to do so.[245] On 12 April, in the
[2016–17 UEFA Champions League](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_UEFA_Champions_League
"2016–17 UEFA Champions League") quarter-final against Bayern Munich, Ronaldo
scored two goals in a 2–1 away win to give Madrid the win and the lead going
into the second leg. The two goals saw him make history in becoming the first
player to reach 100 goals in UEFA club competition.[246] During the second leg
of the quarter-finals, Ronaldo scored a perfect hat-trick and reached his
100th UEFA Champions League goal, becoming the first player to do so as Real
Madrid again defeated Bayern 4–2 after [extra-time](/wiki/Overtime_\(sports\)
"Overtime \(sports\)").[247] On 2 May, Ronaldo scored another hat-trick in the
following Champions League match, as Real Madrid defeated Atlético Madrid 3–0
in the semi-final first leg. His hat-trick made him the first player to reach
50 goals in the knockout stage of the competition.[248]

On 17 May, Ronaldo overtook [Jimmy Greaves](/wiki/Jimmy_Greaves "Jimmy
Greaves") as the all-time top scorer in the top five European leagues, scoring
a brace against Celta de Vigo.[249] He finished the season with 42 goals in
all competitions as he helped Madrid to win their [first La
Liga](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_La_Liga "2016–17 La Liga") title since
2012[250][251] and the first team to win back-to-back finals in the Champions
League era; the first to win consecutive European titles in the competition
since Milan in 1989 and 1990, when the tournament was known as the European
Cup.[252] In the [2017 final](/wiki/2017_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2017
UEFA Champions League Final"), he scored two goals in the victory against
Juventus and became the top goalscorer for the fifth-straight season, and
sixth overall, with 12 goals, while also becoming the first person to score in
three finals in the Champions League era as well as reaching his 600th senior
career goal.[253] Real Madrid's title was its 12th, also known as _La
Duodécima_ , extending its record, and its third in four years.[254][255]

At the start of the 2017–18 season, Ronaldo scored Madrid's second goal in a
3–1 [Supercopa de España](/wiki/2017_Supercopa_de_Espa%C3%B1a "2017 Supercopa
de España") first-leg victory over Barcelona at Camp Nou. Having received a
yellow card for taking his shirt off during his goal celebration, he was sent
off for a second yellow card offence minutes later before he shoved the
referee lightly to depict his dissatisfaction.[256] He was issued a five-match
suspension following the match.[257][258] In his 400th game for Real Madrid,
Ronaldo scored two goals away to Borussia Dortmund in the Champions League,
taking his club tally to 411 goals.[259] On 23 October, his performances in
the first half of 2017 saw him claim his fifth FIFA Player of the Year award
by receiving [The Best FIFA Men's
Player](/wiki/The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2017#The_Best_FIFA_Men's_Player
"The Best FIFA Football Awards 2017") award for the second consecutive
year.[260] On 6 December, he became the first player to score in all six
Champions League group stage matches with a curling strike at home to Borussia
Dortmund.[261] A day later, Ronaldo won the [Ballon
d'Or](/wiki/2017_Ballon_d%27Or "2017 Ballon d'Or") for a fifth time, receiving
the award on the [Eiffel Tower](/wiki/Eiffel_Tower "Eiffel Tower") in
Paris.[262] On 3 March 2018, he scored two goals in a 3–1 home win over
Getafe, his first being his 300th La Liga goal in his 286th La Liga
appearance, making him the fastest player to reach this landmark and only the
second player to do so after Lionel Messi.[263] On 18 March, he reached his
50th career hat-trick, scoring four goals in a 6–3 win against
[Girona](/wiki/Girona_FC "Girona FC").[264]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Ronaldo_in_2018.jpg/180px-
Ronaldo_in_2018.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ronaldo_in_2018.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ronaldo_in_2018.jpg "Powiększ")

Ronaldo in the [2018 UEFA Champions League
Final](/wiki/2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2018 UEFA Champions League
Final")

On 3 April, Ronaldo scored the first two goals in a 3–0 away win against
Juventus in the [quarter-
finals](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_UEFA_Champions_League_knockout_phase#Juventus_v_Real_Madrid
"2017–18 UEFA Champions League knockout phase") of the [2017–18 UEFA Champions
League](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_UEFA_Champions_League "2017–18 UEFA Champions
League"), with his second goal being an acrobatic [bicycle
kick](/wiki/Bicycle_kick "Bicycle kick").[265] The goal, described as a
"[PlayStation](/wiki/PlayStation "PlayStation") goal" by Juventus defender
[Andrea Barzagli](/wiki/Andrea_Barzagli "Andrea Barzagli"), garnered him a
standing ovation from the Juventus fans in the stadium, as well as a plethora
of plaudits from peers, pundits and coaches.[266][267][268] The goal was also
his 119th in European competition, more than 465 other clubs which have
participated in the competition; if he were a club, it would be the tenth-
highest scorer in Champions League history.[269] He would score his 650th
career goal in a 1–1 draw against Atlético Madrid on 8 April.[270] On 11
April, he scored the goal Real Madrid needed to advance to the semi-final, in
the second leg of the Champions League quarter-final at home to Juventus, from
a 98th-minute injury time penalty in a 3–1 defeat, with an overall 4–3
aggregate win.[271] It was also his tenth goal against Juventus, a Champions
League record against a single club.[272] In [the final of the
tournament](/wiki/2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2018 UEFA Champions League
Final"), on 26 May, Real Madrid defeated Liverpool 3–1, winning Ronaldo his
fifth Champions League title as Real Madrid completed their third consecutive
Champions League triumph, becoming the first team to do so.[273][note 6] He
finished as the top scorer of the tournament for the sixth consecutive season,
ending the campaign with 15 goals.[274] After the final, Ronaldo referred to
his time with the Champions League winners in the past tense, sparking
speculation that he could leave Real Madrid.[275]

### Juventus

#### 2018–19

After a week of transfer speculation, on 10 July 2018, Ronaldo signed a four-
year contract with Italian club [Juventus](/wiki/Juventus_F.C. "Juventus
F.C.") after completing a €100 million transfer, plus [solidarity
contributions](/wiki/Transfer_\(football\) "Transfer \(football\)") to
Ronaldo's youth clubs and an additional €12 million in other fees.[276] The
transfer was the highest ever for a player over 30 years old,[277] and the
highest ever paid by an Italian club.[278] Upon signing, Ronaldo cited his
need for a new challenge as his rationale for departing Real Madrid.[279][280]
Ronaldo made his official debut for Juventus in their opening Serie A match on
18 August, a 3–2 away win over [Chievo](/wiki/A.C._ChievoVerona "A.C.
ChievoVerona").[281]

## International career

### 2001–07: Youth level and early international career

Ronaldo began his international career with Portugal at the [2001 European
Youth Summer Olympic
Festival](/wiki/2001_European_Youth_Summer_Olympic_Festival "2001 European
Youth Summer Olympic Festival"), debuting in a 3–1 defeat to Finland.[282] The
following year he would represent his country under-17 side at the [2002 UEFA
European Under-17 Football
Championship](/wiki/2002_UEFA_European_Under-17_Football_Championship "2002
UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship"), where they failed to progress
past the group stage.[23] Ronaldo also featured in the Olympic squad at the
[2004 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/Football_at_the_2004_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_tournament
"Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament"), scoring one goal
in the tournament, though the team was eliminated in the first round,
finishing bottom of their group with three points after 4–2 defeats to
eventual semi-finalists [Iraq](/wiki/Iraq_national_under-23_football_team
"Iraq national under-23 football team") and quarter-finalists [Costa
Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica_national_under-23_football_team "Costa Rica national
under-23 football team").[283][284] During his international youth career,
Ronaldo would go on to represent the under-15 team,
[under-17](/wiki/Portugal_national_under-17_football_team "Portugal national
under-17 football team"),
[under-20](/wiki/Portugal_national_under-20_football_team "Portugal national
under-20 football team"),
[under-21](/wiki/Portugal_national_under-21_football_team "Portugal national
under-21 football team"), and [under-23](/wiki/Portugal_Olympic_football_team
"Portugal Olympic football team") national sides, amassing 34 youth caps and
scoring 18 goals overall.[285]

At age 18, Ronaldo made his first senior appearance for
[Portugal](/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team "Portugal national football
team") in a 1–0 victory over
[Kazakhstan](/wiki/Kazakhstan_national_football_team "Kazakhstan national
football team") on 20 August 2003.[286] He was subsequently called up for
[UEFA Euro 2004](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2004 "UEFA Euro 2004"), held in his home
country, and scored his first international goal in a 2–1 group stage loss to
eventual champions [Greece](/wiki/Greece_national_football_team "Greece
national football team").[287] After converting his penalty in a shootout
against [England](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national
football team") at the quarter-final stage,[288] he helped Portugal reach the
[final](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2004_Final "UEFA Euro 2004 Final") by scoring the
opening goal in a 2–1 win over the
[Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team "Netherlands national
football team"),[289] but the crucial last match ended in a 0–1 defeat.[290]
He was featured in the [team of the
tournament](/wiki/UEFA_European_Football_Championship_Teams_of_the_Tournament
"UEFA European Football Championship Teams of the Tournament"), having
provided two assists in addition to his two goals.[291]

Ronaldo was the second-highest scorer in the [European
qualification](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_\(UEFA\) "2006 FIFA
World Cup qualification \(UEFA\)") for the [2006 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup") with seven goals.[292]
During the tournament, he scored his first World Cup goal against
[Iran](/wiki/Iran_national_football_team "Iran national football team") with a
penalty kick in Portugal's second match of the group stage.[293] In the
quarter-finals against England, his Manchester United teammate Wayne Rooney
was sent off for stamping on Portugal defender [Ricardo
Carvalho](/wiki/Ricardo_Carvalho "Ricardo Carvalho"). Although the referee
later clarified that the red card was only due to Rooney's infraction,[294]
the English media speculated that Ronaldo had influenced his decision by
aggressively complaining, after which he was seen in replays winking at
Portugal's bench following Rooney's dismissal.[295] Ronaldo went on to score
the vital winning penalty during the penalty shoot out which sent Portugal
into the semi-finals.[296] Ronaldo was subsequently booed during their 1–0
semi-final defeat to [France](/wiki/France_national_football_team "France
national football team").[297] FIFA's Technical Study Group overlooked him for
the tournament's Best Young Player award and handed it to
[Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national football
team")'s [Lukas Podolski](/wiki/Lukas_Podolski "Lukas Podolski"), citing his
behaviour as a factor in the decision.[298] Following the 2006 World Cup,
Ronaldo would go on to represent Portugal in four qualifying games for Euro
2008, scoring two goals in the process.[299][300]

### 2007–12: Assuming the captaincy

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Cristiano_Ronaldo_20120609.jpg/170px-
Cristiano_Ronaldo_20120609.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_20120609.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_20120609.jpg "Powiększ")

Ronaldo, pictured playing against
[Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national football
team") at [Euro 2012](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012 "UEFA Euro 2012"), was made captain
in 2008.

One day after his 22nd birthday, Ronaldo
[captained](/wiki/List_of_Portugal_national_football_team_captains "List of
Portugal national football team captains") Portugal for the first time in a
friendly game against [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil
national football team") on 6 February 2007,[301] as requested by [Portuguese
Football Federation](/wiki/Portuguese_Football_Federation "Portuguese Football
Federation") president Carlos Silva, who had died two days earlier.[302] Ahead
of [Euro 2008](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008 "UEFA Euro 2008"), he was given the number
7 shirt for the first time.[303] While he scored eight goals in the
[qualification](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008_qualification "UEFA Euro 2008
qualification"),[304] the second-highest tally, he scored just one goal in the
tournament, netting the second goal of their 3–1 win in the group stage match
against the [Czech Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic_national_football_team
"Czech Republic national football team"); in the same game, he also set-up
Portugal's third goal in injury time, which was scored by Quaresma, and was
named man of the match for his performance.[305][306] Portugal were eliminated
in the quarter-finals with a 3–2 loss against eventual finalists Germany.[307]

After Portugal's unsuccessful performance in the European Championship, [Luiz
Felipe Scolari](/wiki/Luiz_Felipe_Scolari "Luiz Felipe Scolari") was replaced
as coach by Carlos Queiroz, formerly the assistant manager at United.[308]
Queiroz made Ronaldo the squad's permanent captain in July 2008.[309] Ronaldo
failed to score a single goal in the
[qualification](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_\(UEFA\) "2010 FIFA
World Cup qualification \(UEFA\)") for the [2010 World
Cup](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World Cup"), as Portugal narrowly
avoided a premature elimination from the tournament with a play-off victory
over [Bosnia](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_national_football_team "Bosnia and
Herzegovina national football team").[310] At the group stage of the World
Cup, he was named man of the match in all three matches against [Côte
d'Ivoire](/wiki/C%C3%B4te_d%27Ivoire_national_football_team "Côte d'Ivoire
national football team"), [North
Korea](/wiki/North_Korea_national_football_team "North Korea national football
team"), and Brazil.[311][312][313] His only goal of the tournament came in
their 7–0 rout of North Korea,[314] which marked his first international goal
in 16 months.[315] Portugal's World Cup ended with a 1–0 loss against eventual
champions [Spain](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national football
team") in the round of 16.[316]

Ronaldo scored seven goals in the
[qualification](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012_qualifying "UEFA Euro 2012 qualifying")
for [Euro 2012](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012 "UEFA Euro 2012"), including two strikes
against Bosnia in the play-offs, to send Portugal into the tournament, where
they were drawn in a "[group of death](/wiki/Group_of_death "Group of
death")".[317] After the opening 0–1 defeat to Germany, he also failed to
score in the 3–2 win against [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark_national_football_team
"Denmark national football team"), missing two clear one-on-one
chances.[318][319] In the last group stage game against the Netherlands,
Ronaldo scored twice to secure a 2–1 victory.[320] He scored a header in the
quarter-finals against the Czech Republic to give his team a 1–0
win.[321][322] In both games against the Netherlands and the Czech Republic he
was named man of the match.[323][324] After the semi-finals against Spain
ended scoreless, with Ronaldo having sent three shots over the bar,[325]
Portugal were eliminated in the penalty shootout. Ronaldo did not take a
penalty as he had been slated to take the unused fifth,[326] a decision that
drew criticism.[327][328][329] As the joint top scorer with three goals,
alongside five other players, he was again included in the team of the
tournament.[330]

### 2012–16: All-time Portugal top scorer and European champion

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Cristiano_Ronaldo_%28L%29%2C_Luka_Modric_%28R%29_-_Croatia_vs._Portugal%2C_10th_June_2013.jpg/220px-
Cristiano_Ronaldo_%28L%29%2C_Luka_Modric_%28R%29_-_Croatia_vs._Portugal%2C_10th_June_2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_\(L\),_Luka_Modric_\(R\)_-_Croatia_vs._Portugal,_10th_June_2013.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_\(L\),_Luka_Modric_\(R\)_-_Croatia_vs._Portugal,_10th_June_2013.jpg
"Powiększ")

Ronaldo evading [Luka Modrić](/wiki/Luka_Modri%C4%87 "Luka Modrić") during a
friendly match against [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia_national_football_team "Croatia
national football team") in June 2013

During the [qualification](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_\(UEFA\)
"2014 FIFA World Cup qualification \(UEFA\)") for the [2014 World
Cup](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World Cup"), Ronaldo scored a total
of eight goals. A qualifying match on 17 October 2012, a 1–1 draw against
[Northern Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_national_football_team "Northern
Ireland national football team"), earned him his [100th
cap](/wiki/List_of_footballers_with_100_or_more_caps "List of footballers with
100 or more caps").[331] His first international hat-trick also came against
Northern Ireland, when he found the net three times in a 15-minute spell of a
4–2 qualifying victory on 6 September 2013.[332] After Portugal failed to
qualify during the regular campaign, Ronaldo scored all four of the team's
goals in the play-offs against [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden_national_football_team
"Sweden national football team"), which ensured their place at the
tournament.[333] His hat-trick in the second leg took his international tally
to 47 goals, equaling [Pauleta](/wiki/Pauleta "Pauleta")'s record.[334]
Ronaldo subsequently scored twice in a 5–1 friendly win over
[Cameroon](/wiki/Cameroon_national_football_team "Cameroon national football
team") on 5 March 2014 to become his country's [all-time top
scorer](/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team#Top_goalscorers "Portugal
national football team").[335]

Ronaldo took part in the tournament despite suffering from patellar tendinitis
and a related thigh injury,[336][337] potentially risking his career.[338]
Ronaldo later commented: "If we had two or three Cristiano Ronaldos in the
team I would feel more comfortable. But we don't."[339] Despite ongoing doubts
over his fitness, being forced to abort practice twice,[340][341] Ronaldo
played the full 90 minutes of the opening match against Germany, though he was
unable to prevent a 4–0 defeat.[342] After assisting an injury-time 2–2
equaliser against the [United
States](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_soccer_team "United States men's
national soccer team"),[343] he scored a late match-winning goal in a 2–1
victory over [Ghana](/wiki/Ghana_national_football_team "Ghana national
football team").[344] His [50th international
goal](/wiki/List_of_men%27s_footballers_with_50_or_more_international_goals
"List of men's footballers with 50 or more international goals") made him the
first Portuguese to play and score in three World Cups.[345] Portugal were
eliminated from the tournament at the close of the group stage on goal
difference.[344]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/1_cristiano_ronaldo_2016.jpg/170px-1_cristiano_ronaldo_2016.jpg)](/wiki/File:1_cristiano_ronaldo_2016.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1_cristiano_ronaldo_2016.jpg "Powiększ")

Ronaldo leaps in the air in Portugal’s [Euro 2016](/wiki/Euro_2016 "Euro
2016") quarter-final match against
[Poland](/wiki/Poland_national_football_team "Poland national football team")

Ronaldo scored five goals, including a hat-trick against
[Armenia](/wiki/Armenia_national_football_team "Armenia national football
team"), in the [qualification](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016_qualifying "UEFA Euro 2016
qualifying") for [Euro 2016](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016 "UEFA Euro
2016").[346][347][348][349] With the only goal in another victory over Armenia
on 14 November 2014, he reached 23 goals in the European Championship,
including qualifying matches, to become the competition's [all-time leading
goalscorer](/wiki/List_of_UEFA_European_Championship_records#Goalscoring "List
of UEFA European Championship records").[350] At the start of the tournament,
however, Ronaldo failed to convert his chances in Portugal's draws against
[Iceland](/wiki/Iceland_national_football_team "Iceland national football
team") and [Austria](/wiki/Austria_national_football_team "Austria national
football team"), despite taking a total of 20 shots on goal. In the latter
match, he overtook Luís Figo as his [nation's most capped
player](/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team#Most_appearances "Portugal
national football team") with his 128th international appearance, which ended
scoreless after he missed a penalty in the second half.[351] With two goals
and an assist in the last match of the group stage, a 3–3 draw against
[Hungary](/wiki/Hungary_national_football_team "Hungary national football
team"), Ronaldo became the first player to score in four European
Championships, having made a [record 17
appearances](/wiki/List_of_UEFA_European_Championship_records#Individual "List
of UEFA European Championship records") in the tournament.[352][353] Though
placed third in their group behind Hungary and Iceland, his team qualified for
the knockout round as a result of the competition's newly expanded
format.[354]

In Portugal's first knockout match, Ronaldo's only attempt on goal was parried
by [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia_national_football_team "Croatia national football
team")'s goalkeeper into the path of [Ricardo Quaresma](/wiki/Ricardo_Quaresma
"Ricardo Quaresma"), whose finish then secured a 1–0 victory late in extra
time.[355] After his team progressed past
[Poland](/wiki/Poland_national_football_team "Poland national football team")
on penalties,[356] Ronaldo became the first player to participate in three
European Championship semi-finals;[357] he scored the opening goal and
assisted a second in a 2–0 win against
[Wales](/wiki/Wales_national_football_team "Wales national football team"),
equaling [Michel Platini](/wiki/Michel_Platini "Michel Platini") as the
competition's all-time top scorer with nine goals.[358] In the
[final](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016_Final "UEFA Euro 2016 Final") against hosts
France, Ronaldo was forced off after just 25 minutes following a challenge
from [Dimitri Payet](/wiki/Dimitri_Payet "Dimitri Payet"). After multiple
treatments and attempts to play on, he was stretchered off the pitch and
replaced by Quaresma. During extra time, substitute
[Eder](/wiki/Eder_\(Portuguese_footballer\) "Eder \(Portuguese footballer\)")
scored in the 109th minute to earn Portugal a 1–0 victory.[359] As team
captain, Ronaldo later lifted the trophy in celebration of his country's
first-ever triumph in a major tournament. He was awarded the [Silver
Boot](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016#Awards "UEFA Euro 2016") as the joint second-
highest goalscorer, with three goals and three assists, and was named to the
team of the tournament for the third time in his career.[360][361]

### 2016–present: Post-European Championship victory, and World Cup

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Cristiano_Ronaldo_2017.jpg/170px-
Cristiano_Ronaldo_2017.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_2017.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_2017.jpg "Powiększ")

Ronaldo playing against [Russia](/wiki/Russia_national_football_team "Russia
national football team") at the [2017 FIFA Confederations
Cup](/wiki/2017_FIFA_Confederations_Cup "2017 FIFA Confederations Cup")

Following the Euro 2016 success, Ronaldo scored four goals against Andorra in
the [2018 FIFA World Cup qualifiers](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification
"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification") on 8 October 2016. His four goals against
a nine-man team marked the highest number of goals he has scored in an
international match.[362][363] On 13 November, Ronaldo scored two goals (while
also missing a penalty) in another qualifier against
[Latvia](/wiki/Latvia_national_football_team "Latvia national football team"),
which ended in a 4–1 home victory. These goals brought his international tally
to 68 goals, putting level with [Gerd Müller](/wiki/Gerd_M%C3%BCller "Gerd
Müller") and [Robbie Keane](/wiki/Robbie_Keane "Robbie Keane") as the fourth-
highest European international goalscorer of all-time.[364] He played his
first professional match on his home island of Madeira on 28 March 2017 at age
32, opening a 2–3 friendly defeat to Sweden at the [Estádio dos
Barreiros](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_dos_Barreiros "Estádio dos Barreiros"). With the
goal, he tied with [Miroslav Klose](/wiki/Miroslav_Klose "Miroslav Klose") on
71 goals as the third-highest scoring European in international football.[365]

In Portugal's opening match of the [2017 FIFA Confederations
Cup](/wiki/2017_FIFA_Confederations_Cup "2017 FIFA Confederations Cup")
against [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico_national_football_team "Mexico national football
team") on 17 June, Cristiano Ronaldo set-up Quaresma's opening goal in a 2–2
draw.[366] Three days later, he scored in a 1–0 win over hosts
[Russia](/wiki/Russia_national_football_team "Russia national football
team").[367] On 24 June, he scored from a penalty in a 4–0 win over [New
Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand_national_football_team "New Zealand national
football team"), which saw Portugal top their group and advance to the semi-
finals of the competition. With his 75th international goal, Ronaldo also
equalled [Sándor Kocsis](/wiki/S%C3%A1ndor_Kocsis "Sándor Kocsis") as the
second-highest European international goalscorer of all-time, behind only
Ferenc Puskás.[368][369] He was named man of the match in all three of
Portugal's group stage matches.[370] Ronaldo left the competition early: after
[Chile](/wiki/Chile_national_football_team "Chile national football team")
defeated Portugal 3–0 on penalties in the [semi-
finals](/wiki/2017_FIFA_Confederations_Cup#Semi-finals "2017 FIFA
Confederations Cup"), he was allowed to return home to be with his newborn
children.[371] Therefore, he missed Portugal's [third-place play-
off](/wiki/2017_FIFA_Confederations_Cup#Third_place_play-off "2017 FIFA
Confederations Cup") match in which Portugal defeated Mexico 2–1 after extra
time.[372]
