On 31 August 2017, Ronaldo scored a hat-trick in a 5–1 win in a World Cup
qualifier over the [Faroe Islands](/wiki/Faroe_Islands_national_football_team
"Faroe Islands national football team"), which saw him overtake Pelé and equal
[Hussein Saeed](/wiki/Hussein_Saeed "Hussein Saeed") as the joint-fifth-
highest goalscorer in international football with 78 goals.[373] These goals
brought his tally in the 2018 World Cup qualifiers to 14, equalling [Predrag
Mijatović](/wiki/Predrag_Mijatovi%C4%87 "Predrag Mijatović")'s record for most
goals in a single UEFA senior men's qualifying campaign, and also saw him
break the record for the most goals scored in a single European qualifying
group, overtaking the previous record of 13 goals set by [David
Healy](/wiki/David_Healy_\(footballer\) "David Healy \(footballer\)") and
[Robert Lewandowski](/wiki/Robert_Lewandowski "Robert Lewandowski"). Ronaldo's
hat-trick took his World Cup qualifying goals total to 29, making him the
highest scorer in European World Cup qualifiers, ahead of [Andriy
Shevchenko](/wiki/Andriy_Shevchenko "Andriy Shevchenko"), and the highest
goalscorer in World Cup qualifying and finals matches combined, with 32 goals,
ahead of Miroslav Klose.[374] Ronaldo later added to this tally by scoring a
goal against Andorra in a 2–0 victory.[375]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Portugal_and_Iran_match_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup_2018_9.jpg/220px-
Portugal_and_Iran_match_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup_2018_9.jpg)](/wiki/File:Portugal_and_Iran_match_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup_2018_9.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Portugal_and_Iran_match_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup_2018_9.jpg
"Powiększ")

Ronaldo evades an [Iran](/wiki/Iran_national_football_team "Iran national
football team") defender in the group stage of the [2018 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup") in Russia

In the build-up to the [2018 World Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA
World Cup"), Portugal hosted friendlies against
[Tunisia](/wiki/Tunisia_national_football_team "Tunisia national football
team"), [Belgium](/wiki/Belgium_national_football_team "Belgium national
football team") and [Algeria](/wiki/Algeria_national_football_team "Algeria
national football team"). Ronaldo featured in the final of the three matches
in which he made his 150th international appearance.[376] On 15 June 2018,
Ronaldo became the oldest player ever to score a [hat-
trick](/wiki/List_of_FIFA_World_Cup_hat-tricks "List of FIFA World Cup hat-
tricks") in a World Cup match, helping Portugal secure a 3–3 draw against
Spain in their opening match at the World Cup. In doing so, he also became the
first Portuguese player to score a goal in four World Cups and one of four
players to do so in total.[377] His third goal saw him curl in a 30 yard free
kick with two minutes remaining for the equaliser.[378] His hat-trick also
drew him level with [Ferenc Puskás](/wiki/Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s "Ferenc Puskás")
as the highest European goalscorer of all-time, with 84 international
goals.[379] In Portugal’s second game on 20 June, Ronaldo scored the only goal
in a 1–0 victory against [Morocco](/wiki/Morocco_national_football_team
"Morocco national football team"), breaking Puskás' record.[7] In the final
group match against [Iran](/wiki/Iran_national_football_team "Iran national
football team") on 25 June, Ronaldo missed a penalty in an eventual 1–1 draw
which saw Portugal progress to the second round as group runners-up behind
Spain.[380] On 30 June, Portugal were eliminated following a 2–1 defeat to
[Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay national football
team") in the last 16.[381]

## Player profile

### Style of play

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Cristiano_Ronaldo_2012_Espanyol.jpg/220px-
Cristiano_Ronaldo_2012_Espanyol.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_2012_Espanyol.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_2012_Espanyol.jpg "Powiększ")

Ronaldo in action for Real Madrid against [Espanyol](/wiki/RCD_Espanyol "RCD
Espanyol") during the 2012–13 season

A versatile [attacker](/wiki/Forward_\(association_football\) "Forward
\(association football\)"), Ronaldo is capable of playing on either wing as
well as through the centre of the pitch,[382] and, while ostensibly right-
footed, is very strong with both feet.[383] He ranks among the world's fastest
footballers, both with and without the ball.[384] Tactically, Ronaldo has
undergone several evolutions throughout his career. While at Sporting and
during his first season at Manchester United, he was typically deployed as a
traditional [winger](/wiki/Midfielder#Winger "Midfielder") on the right side
of midfield, where he regularly looked to deliver
[crosses](/wiki/Cross_\(football\) "Cross \(football\)") into the penalty
area. In this position, he was able to use his pace and acceleration, agility,
and technical skills to take on opponents in one-on-one situations. Ronaldo
became noted for his [dribbling](/wiki/Dribbling#Association_football
"Dribbling") and flair, often displaying an array of
[tricks](/wiki/Association_football_tactics_and_skills "Association football
tactics and skills") and [feints](/wiki/Dummy_\(football\) "Dummy
\(football\)"),[384][385] such as the [step overs](/wiki/Step_over "Step
over") that became his trademark.[386]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Contr%C3%B4le_de_Cristiano_Ronaldo.jpg/220px-
Contr%C3%B4le_de_Cristiano_Ronaldo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Contr%C3%B4le_de_Cristiano_Ronaldo.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Contr%C3%B4le_de_Cristiano_Ronaldo.jpg "Powiększ")

Ronaldo controlling the ball on his chest during a 2010–11 La Liga game
against [Almería](/wiki/UD_Almer%C3%ADa "UD Almería")

As Ronaldo matured, he underwent a major physical transformation, developing a
muscular body type that allows him to retain possession of the ball.[387] His
strength, combined with his elevation and height of 1.85 m (6 ft 1 in), gives
him an edge in winning aerial challenges for balls. These attributes allow him
to function as a target-man, and makes him an aerial goal threat in the
penalty area; consequently, many of his goals have been
headers.[388][389][390] Allied with his increased stamina and work-rate, his
goalscoring ability improved drastically on the left wing where he was given
the positional freedom to move into the centre to finish attacks. He also
increasingly played a [creative role](/wiki/Playmaker "Playmaker") for his
team, often dropping deep to pick up the ball, participate in the build-up of
plays, and create chances for his teammates, courtesy of his good vision and
passing ability.[384][388]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Cristiano_Ronaldo_free_Kick_%285628686024%29.jpg/220px-
Cristiano_Ronaldo_free_Kick_%285628686024%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_free_Kick_\(5628686024\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_free_Kick_\(5628686024\).jpg "Powiększ")

Pictured during _[El Clásico](/wiki/El_Cl%C3%A1sico "El Clásico")_ in 2011,
Ronaldo in his familiar pose before striking a free kick

In his final seasons at United, Ronaldo played an even more attacking and
central role, functioning both as a
[striker](/wiki/Forward_\(association_football\)#Striker "Forward
\(association football\)") and as a [supporting
forward](/wiki/Forward_\(association_football\)#Second_striker "Forward
\(association football\)"), or even as an [attacking
midfielder](/wiki/Midfielder#Attacking_midfielder "Midfielder") on
occasion.[391] He developed into a prolific goalscorer, capable of finishing
well both inside the penalty area and from distance with an accurate and
powerful shot, courtesy of his striking ability.[388][391][392] An accurate
[penalty kick](/wiki/Penalty_kick_\(association_football\) "Penalty kick
\(association football\)") taker,[393] he also became a set piece specialist,
renowned for his powerful, [bending](/wiki/Curl_\(football\) "Curl
\(football\)") [free kicks](/wiki/Direct_free_kick "Direct free kick"),[394]
though his ability in this regard deteriorated later on in his
career.[395][396]

At Real Madrid, Ronaldo continued to play a more offensive role, while his
creative and defensive duties became more limited, although not entirely
diminished.[391] Initially deployed as a [centre
forward](/wiki/Forward_\(association_football\)#Centre-forward "Forward
\(association football\)"), he was later moved back onto the left wing, though
in a free tactical role; this position allowed him to drift into the centre at
will to get onto the end of crosses and score, or draw out defenders with his
movement off the ball and leave space for teammates to exploit.[388][397][398]
Madrid's counter-attacking style of play also allowed him to become a more
efficient and consistent player, as evidenced by his record-breaking
goalscoring feats. However, while he mainly drew praise in the media for his
prolific goalscoring, he also demonstrated his ability as an effective creator
in this role.[399][400][401] From 2013 onwards, he effectively adapted his
style to the physical effects of ageing with increasingly reduced off-the-ball
movement and general involvement, completing fewer dribbles and passes per
game, and instead focusing on short-distance creating and
goalscoring.[386][402][403] Since 2017, Ronaldo has adapted his style of play
yet again to become more of a free-roaming centre forward, a role in which he
has continued to excel and maintain a prolific goalscoring record; in this
position, he has earned praise in the media for his intelligent movement,
excellent positional sense, link-up play, clinical finishing, and opportunism,
as well as his ability to lose or anticipate his markers, find space in the
box, and score from few opportunities.[404][405][406]

### Reception

"In the six years [Manchester United] had him, you just saw his game grow all
the time, and he was a fantastic player. Now you see the complete player. His
decision-making, his maturity, his experience, plus all the great skills he
has got, they all make him the complete player."

– Former manager Alex Ferguson, January 2013[407]

Ronaldo is widely regarded as one of the two best players of his generation,
alongside [Lionel Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi").[note 7] Ronaldo
quickly established himself among the world's best players in his early 20s,
featuring as the core component for Manchester United in the mid-to-late
2000s.[408] However, after winning his first [Ballon
d'Or](/wiki/2008_Ballon_d%27Or "2008 Ballon d'Or") by a record-high vote count
at age 23, the public debate regarding his qualities as a player moved beyond
his status in contemporary football to the possibility that he was one of the
greatest players in history.[409] Universally acclaimed for his prolific and
consistent goalscoring ability,[note 8] he is considered a decisive player,
who stands out in games and who can be a game changer,[410] especially in
important and high-pressured situations.[note 9] Ronaldo is noted for his work
ethic, elite body conditioning, and dedication to improvement on the training
pitch, as well being regarded as a natural leader.[411][412][413] His drive
and determination to succeed are fuelled by a desire to be talked about
alongside [Pelé](/wiki/Pel%C3%A9 "Pelé") and [Diego
Maradona](/wiki/Diego_Maradona "Diego Maradona") once retiring.[414]

Ronaldo has at times, however, been criticised for
[simulating](/wiki/Diving_\(association_football\) "Diving \(association
football\)") when tackled.[note 10] In addition to this, he was also
occasionally criticised early in his career by manager Alex Ferguson,
teammates and the media for being a selfish or overly flamboyant
player.[415][416]

During his career, Ronaldo has also been described as having an "arrogant
image" on the pitch,[413] with Ronaldo stating that he had become a "victim",
because of how he was portrayed in the media.[417] He is often seen moaning,
gesticulating and scowling while trying to inspire his team to victory,[413]
with Ronaldo insisting that his competitive nature should not be mistaken for
arrogance.[417] His managers, teammates and various journalists have commented
that this reputation has caused an unfair image of
him.[418][419][420][421][422] In 2014, Ronaldo told _[France
Football](/wiki/France_Football "France Football")_ that he had made a
"mistake" when he said in 2011, "People are jealous of me as I am young,
handsome and rich", adding that he had matured since then and fans understood
him better.[423]

### Comparisons to Lionel Messi

Main article: [Messi–Ronaldo rivalry](/wiki/Messi%E2%80%93Ronaldo_rivalry
"Messi–Ronaldo rivalry")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Cristiano_Ronaldo_and_Lionel_Messi_-
_Portugal_vs_Argentina%2C_9th_February_2011.jpg/191px-
Cristiano_Ronaldo_and_Lionel_Messi_-
_Portugal_vs_Argentina%2C_9th_February_2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_and_Lionel_Messi_-
_Portugal_vs_Argentina,_9th_February_2011.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_and_Lionel_Messi_-
_Portugal_vs_Argentina,_9th_February_2011.jpg "Powiększ")

Ronaldo with [Lionel Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi") before an
[international friendly](/wiki/Exhibition_match "Exhibition match") between
[Portugal](/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team "Portugal national football
team") and [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina
national football team") in Geneva, Switzerland, on 9 February 2011

Both players have scored in at least two [UEFA Champions
League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League") finals and have
regularly broken the 50-goal barrier in a single season. Sports journalists
and pundits regularly argue the individual merits of both players in an
attempt to argue who they believe is the best player in modern football.[424]
It has been compared to [sports rivalries](/wiki/List_of_sports_rivalries
"List of sports rivalries") such as the [Muhammad Ali](/wiki/Muhammad_Ali
"Muhammad Ali")–[Joe Frazier](/wiki/Joe_Frazier "Joe Frazier") rivalry in
boxing, the [Borg–McEnroe rivalry](/wiki/Borg%E2%80%93McEnroe_rivalry
"Borg–McEnroe rivalry") in tennis, and the [Ayrton Senna](/wiki/Ayrton_Senna
"Ayrton Senna")–[Alain Prost](/wiki/Alain_Prost "Alain Prost") rivalry from
[Formula One](/wiki/Formula_One "Formula One") motor racing.[425][426]

"It's part of my life now. People are bound to compare us. He tries to do his
best for his club and for his national team, as I do, and there is a degree of
rivalry with both of us trying to do the best for the teams we represent."

—Cristiano Ronaldo commenting on his rivalry with Messi.[427]

Some commentators choose to analyse the differing physiques and playing styles
of the two,[428] while part of the debate revolves around the contrasting
personalities of the two players: Ronaldo is sometimes depicted as an arrogant
and theatrical showoff, while Messi is portrayed as a shy, humble
character.[429][430][431][432]

In a 2012 interview, Ronaldo commented on the rivalry, saying "I think we push
each other sometimes in the competition, this is why the competition is so
high",[433] while Ronaldo's manager during his time at [Manchester
United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United F.C."), [Alex
Ferguson](/wiki/Alex_Ferguson "Alex Ferguson"), opined that "I don't think the
rivalry against each other bothers them. I think they have their own personal
pride in terms of wanting to be the best".[434] Messi himself denied any
rivalry, saying that it was "only the media, the press, who wants us to be at
loggerheads but I've never fought with Cristiano".[435] Responding to the
claims that he and Messi do not get on well on a personal level, Ronaldo
commented, "We don't have a relationship outside the world of football, just
as we don't with a lot of other players", before adding that in years to come
he hopes they can laugh about it together, stating; "We have to look on this
rivalry with a positive spirit, because it's a good thing."[427] Representing
archrivals Barcelona and Real Madrid, the two players faced each other at
least twice every season in the world's biggest club game, _[El
Clásico](/wiki/El_Cl%C3%A1sico "El Clásico")_ , which is among the world’s
most viewed annual sporting events.[436]

In a debate at [Oxford Union](/wiki/Oxford_Union "Oxford Union") in October
2013, when asked whether FIFA president Sepp Blatter preferred Messi or
Ronaldo, Blatter paid tribute to the work ethic of the Argentine before taking
a swipe at Ronaldo, claiming "one of them has more expenses for the
hairdresser than the other". Real Madrid demanded – and promptly received – a
full apology, and the Portuguese issued his own riposte with a mock-salute
celebration after scoring a penalty against Sevilla, after Blatter had
described him as a "commander" on the pitch.[437]

Ronaldo's CR7 Museum – front view

As his reputation grew from his time at Manchester United, Ronaldo has signed
many sponsorship deals for consumer products, including sportswear, football
boots (since November 2012 Ronaldo has worn the [Nike Mercurial
Vapor](/wiki/Nike_Mercurial_Vapor "Nike Mercurial Vapor") personalized CR7
edition),[438] soft drinks, clothing, automotive lubricants, financial
services, electronics and computer video
games.[439][440][441][442][443][444][445][446] Ronaldo was featured as the
cover athlete of EA Sports' [_FIFA_ video
game](/wiki/FIFA_\(video_game_series\) "FIFA \(video game series\)") _[FIFA
18](/wiki/FIFA_18 "FIFA 18")_ and was heavily involved in the game's
promotion.[447] He was also the face of _[Pro Evolution
Soccer](/wiki/Pro_Evolution_Soccer "Pro Evolution Soccer")_ , appearing on the
cover in [2008](/wiki/Pro_Evolution_Soccer_2008 "Pro Evolution Soccer 2008"),
[2012](/wiki/Pro_Evolution_Soccer_2012 "Pro Evolution Soccer 2012") and
[2013](/wiki/Pro_Evolution_Soccer_2013 "Pro Evolution Soccer 2013").[448]

_[Forbes](/wiki/Forbes "Forbes")_ has twice ranked Ronaldo first on its list
of the world's highest-paid football players; his combined income from
salaries, bonuses and non-football earnings was $73 million in 2013–14 and $79
million in 2014–15.[449][450] The latter earnings saw him listed behind only
boxer [Floyd Mayweather, Jr.](/wiki/Floyd_Mayweather,_Jr. "Floyd Mayweather,
Jr.") on the magazine's list of The World's Highest-Paid Athletes.[451] In
2016, he became the first footballer to top the _Forbes_ list of highest-
earning athletes, with a total income of $88 million from his salary and
endorsements in 2015–16.[452] He topped the list for the second straight year
with earnings of $93 million in 2016–17.[453] Ronaldo is one of the world's
most marketable athletes: _[SportsPro](/wiki/SportsPro "SportsPro")_ rated him
the fifth most marketable athlete in 2012,[454] and eighth most marketable
athlete in 2013, with Brazilian footballer [Neymar](/wiki/Neymar "Neymar")
topping both lists.[454][455] Sports market research company Repucom named
Ronaldo the most marketable and most recognised football player in the world
in May 2014.[456] He was additionally named in the 2014 [Time
100](/wiki/Time_100 "Time 100"), _[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time
\(magazine\)")_ 's annual list of the most influential people in the
world.[457] [ESPN](/wiki/ESPN "ESPN") named Ronaldo the world's most famous
athlete in 2016, 2017 and 2018.[458][459][460]

Ronaldo has established a strong online presence; the most popular
sportsperson on social media, he counted 158 million total followers across
Facebook, Twitter and [Instagram](/wiki/Instagram "Instagram") by June
2015.[461] As of June 2015, he has the world's biggest Facebook fanbase with
103 million followers:[461] he became the first sportsperson to reach 50
million followers in August 2010,[462] and in October 2014, he became the
first sportsperson, and the second person after [Shakira](/wiki/Shakira
"Shakira"), to reach 100 million followers.[463] By June 2017, Ronaldo had 277
million followers across social media.[453] His sponsors earned $936 million
in media value across his social media accounts between June 2016 to June
2017.[453] Ronaldo has released two mobile apps: in December 2011, he launched
an [iPhone](/wiki/IPhone "IPhone") game called _Heads Up with Cristiano_ ,
created by developer [RockLive](/wiki/RockLive "RockLive"),[464] and in
December 2013, he launched _Viva Ronaldo_ , a dedicated social networking
website and mobile app.[465] Computer security company [McAfee](/wiki/McAfee
"McAfee") produced a 2012 report ranking footballers by the probability of an
internet search for their name leading to an unsafe website, with Ronaldo's
name first on the list.[466]

[](/wiki/File:Madeira_-_Funchal_\(32681018993\).jpg "Powiększ")

Ronaldo statue in Madeira

Ronaldo's life and person have been the subject of several works. His
autobiography, titled _Moments_ , was published in December 2007.[467] His
sponsor Castro produced the television film _Ronaldo: Tested to the Limit_ ,
in which he is physically and mentally tested in several areas; his physical
performance was consequently subject to scrutiny by world media upon the
film's release in September 2011.[468] _[Cristiano Ronaldo: The World at His
Feet](/wiki/Cristiano_Ronaldo:_The_World_at_His_Feet "Cristiano Ronaldo: The
World at His Feet")_ , a documentary narrated by the actor [Benedict
Cumberbatch](/wiki/Benedict_Cumberbatch "Benedict Cumberbatch"), was released
via [Vimeo](/wiki/Vimeo "Vimeo") in June 2014.[469] A documentary film about
his life and career, titled _[Ronaldo](/wiki/Ronaldo_\(film\) "Ronaldo
\(film\)")_ , was released worldwide on 9 November 2015.[470] Directed by
BAFTA-winner [Anthony Wonke](/wiki/Anthony_Wonke "Anthony Wonke"), the film is
produced and distributed by Universal Pictures, while [Asif
Kapadia](/wiki/Asif_Kapadia "Asif Kapadia") is the executive producer.[471]

Ronaldo opened his first fashion boutique under the name _CR7_ (his initials
and shirt number) on the island of Madeira, Portugal, in 2006. Ronaldo
expanded his business with a second clothes boutique in Lisbon in 2008.[472]
In partnership with Scandinavian manufacturer JBS Textile Group and the New
York fashion designer [Richard Chai](/wiki/Richard_Chai "Richard Chai"),
Ronaldo co-designed a range of underwear and sock line, released in November
2013.[473] He later expanded his _CR7_ fashion brand by launching a line of
premium shirts[474] and shoes by July 2014.[475] In September 2015, Ronaldo—in
a partnership with Eden Parfums—released his own fragrance, "Legacy".[476]

Madeira_Funchal_landing_strip_1990.jpg)](/wiki/File:Madeira_Funchal_landing_strip_1990.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Madeira_Funchal_landing_strip_1990.jpg "Powiększ")

[Cristiano Ronaldo International
Airport](/wiki/Cristiano_Ronaldo_International_Airport "Cristiano Ronaldo
International Airport") in Madeira

In 2007, C.D. Nacional renamed its youth campus Cristiano Ronaldo Campus
Futebol (Cristiano Ronaldo Football Campus).[477] In December 2013, Ronaldo
opened a museum, [Museu CR7](/wiki/Museu_CR7 "Museu CR7"), in his hometown of
Funchal, Madeira, to house trophies and memorabilia of his life and playing
career;[478] the museum is an official sponsor of the local football team
[União da Madeira](/wiki/Uni%C3%A3o_da_Madeira "União da Madeira").[479][480]
At a ceremony held at the [Belém Palace](/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_Palace "Belém
Palace") in January 2014, President of Portugal [Aníbal Cavaco
Silva](/wiki/An%C3%ADbal_Cavaco_Silva "Aníbal Cavaco Silva") raised Ronaldo to
the rank of Grand Officer of the [Order of Prince
Henry](/wiki/Order_of_Prince_Henry "Order of Prince Henry"), "to distinguish
an athlete of world renown who has been a symbol of Portugal globally,
contributing to the international projection of the country and setting an
example of tenacity for future generations".[481] A bronze statue of Ronaldo,
designed by artist Ricardo Madeira Veloso, was unveiled in Funchal on 21
December 2014.[482][483]

In June 2010, during the build-up to the World Cup, Ronaldo became the fourth
footballer – after [Steven Gerrard](/wiki/Steven_Gerrard "Steven Gerrard"),
Pelé and David Beckham – to be represented as a waxwork at [Madame Tussauds
London](/wiki/Madame_Tussauds_London "Madame Tussauds London").[484] Another
waxwork of him was presented at the Madrid Wax Museum in December 2013.[485]
In June 2015, astronomers led by David Sobral from Lisbon and
[Leiden](/wiki/Leiden "Leiden") discovered a galaxy which they named CR7
([Cosmos Redshift 7](/wiki/Cosmos_Redshift_7 "Cosmos Redshift 7")) in tribute
to Ronaldo.[486][487]

On 23 July 2016, following Portugal's triumph at Euro 2016, Madeira Airport in
Funchal was renamed the [Cristiano Ronaldo International
Airport](/wiki/Cristiano_Ronaldo_International_Airport "Cristiano Ronaldo
International Airport").[488] The unveiling of the rebranded terminal took
place on 29 March 2017, which included a bust of his head being
presented.[489] The bust and the name change were controversial, with the lack
of the bust's likeness to Ronaldo being ridiculed by comedians, including
_[Saturday Night Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live "Saturday Night Live")_
,[490] while the name change was subject to much debate locally by some
politicians and citizens, who even started a petition against the move, an
action criticised by President of Madeira [Miguel
Albuquerque](/wiki/Miguel_Albuquerque "Miguel Albuquerque").[491][489] A year
later, sports website [Bleacher Report](/wiki/Bleacher_Report "Bleacher
Report") commissioned sculptor [Emanuel Santos](/wiki/Emanuel_Santos "Emanuel
Santos") to create another bust.[492] However, this bust was never used;
instead, a new one was made by a Spanish sculptor, shown to the public on 15
June 2018.[493]

## Personal life

### Family and relationships

show

Ronaldo's children

  * Via a [surrogate mother](/wiki/Surrogate_mother "Surrogate mother")
    * Cristiano Ronaldo dos Santos Junior (born 2010)
  * Via a surrogate mother 
    * Eva Maria (born 2017)
    * Mateo (born 2017)
  * By Georgina Rodriguez 
    * Alana Martina (born 2017)

Ronaldo's father, José Dinis Aveiro, died of an alcoholism-related liver
condition at age 52 in September 2005 when Ronaldo was 20.[494][495] Ronaldo
has said that he [does not drink alcohol](/wiki/Teetotalism "Teetotalism"),
and he received [libel](/wiki/Defamation "Defamation") damages over a _[Daily
Mirror](/wiki/Daily_Mirror "Daily Mirror")_ article that reported him drinking
heavily in a nightclub while recovering from an injury in July 2008.[496]

Ronaldo became father to a son in June 2010, announcing that he had full
custody of the child and would not be publicly revealing the identity of his
son's mother.[497][498][499][500] In January 2015, Ronaldo announced his five-
year relationship with Russian model [Irina Shayk](/wiki/Irina_Shayk "Irina
Shayk") ended.[501][502]

In June 2017, Ronaldo announced he had become the father to twins, a daughter
Eva Maria and a son Mateo.[503] Five months later, his girlfriend Georgina
Rodríguez gave birth to their daughter Alana Martina.[504]

### Philanthropy

Ronaldo has made contributions to various charitable causes throughout his
career. Television footage of the [2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and
tsunami](/wiki/2004_Indian_Ocean_earthquake_and_tsunami "2004 Indian Ocean
earthquake and tsunami") showed an eight-year-old boy survivor named
[Martunis](/wiki/Martunis "Martunis") wearing a number 7 Portuguese football
shirt who was stranded for 19 days after his family was killed. Following
this, Ronaldo visited [Aceh](/wiki/Aceh "Aceh"), Indonesia, to raise funds for
rehabilitation and reconstruction.[505][506] After accepting undisclosed
damages from a libel case against _[The Sun](/wiki/The_Sun_\(United_Kingdom\)
"The Sun \(United Kingdom\)")_ newspaper in 2008, Ronaldo donated the damages
to a charity in [Madeira](/wiki/Madeira "Madeira").[507] In 2009, Ronaldo
donated £100,000 to the hospital that saved his mother's life in
[Madeira](/wiki/Madeira "Madeira") following her battle with cancer, so that
they could build a cancer centre on the island.[508] In support of the victims
of the [2010 Madeira flood](/wiki/2010_Madeira_floods_and_mudslides "2010
Madeira floods and mudslides"), Ronaldo pledged to play in a charity match in
Madeira between Primeira Liga club Porto and players from Madeiran-based clubs
[Marítimo](/wiki/C.S._Mar%C3%ADtimo "C.S. Marítimo") and Nacional.[509]

In 2012, Ronaldo and his agent paid for specialist treatment for a nine-year-
old Canarian boy with apparently terminal cancer.[510] In November 2012,
Ronaldo sold the golden boot he had won in 2011 for €1.5 million and gave the
money to fund schools for children in Gaza.[511] In December 2012, Ronaldo
joined FIFA's "11 for Health" programme to raise awareness amongst kids of how
to steer clear of conditions including drug addiction, HIV, malaria and
obesity.[512]

In January 2013, Ronaldo became [Save the Children](/wiki/Save_the_Children
"Save the Children")'s new Global Artist Ambassador, in which he hopes to help
fight child hunger and obesity.[513] In March, Ronaldo agreed to be the
ambassador for The Mangrove Care Forum in Indonesia, an organisation aiming to
raise awareness of [mangrove](/wiki/Mangrove "Mangrove") conservation.[514]

In November 2014, Ronaldo appeared in FIFA's "11 against
[Ebola](/wiki/Ebola_virus_disease "Ebola virus disease")" campaign with a
selection of top football players from around the world, including
[Neymar](/wiki/Neymar "Neymar"), Gareth Bale, [Xavi](/wiki/Xavi "Xavi") and
[Didier Drogba](/wiki/Didier_Drogba "Didier Drogba").[515] Under the slogan
"Together, we can beat Ebola", FIFA's campaign was done in conjunction with
the [Confederation of African
Football](/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football "Confederation of African
Football") and health experts, with the players holding up 11 messages to
raise awareness of the disease and ways to combat it.[515] He was named the
world's most charitable sportsperson in 2015.[516] In June 2016, Ronaldo
donated the entirety of his €600,000 Champions League bonus after Real Madrid
won the 2015–16 UEFA Champions League.[516]

In August 2016, Ronaldo launched CR7Selfie, a [selfie](/wiki/Selfie "Selfie")
app for charity to help Save the Children that lets participants take a selfie
with him in one of several different outfits and poses.[517] In the app, fans
can select from among 68 photos of Ronaldo in different outfits and poses, and
scroll through 39 filters to apply to their selfies.[518]

### Controversies

In April 2017, a story was published by _[Der Spiegel](/wiki/Der_Spiegel "Der
Spiegel")_ based on leaked documents provided by Football Leaks relating to an
alleged rape by Ronaldo, stating the alleged assault occurred in 2009 but that
a legal agreement and accompanying non-disclosure agreement was entered into,
resulting in the alleged charges being dropped.[519] Ronaldo's agent [Jorge
Mendes](/wiki/Jorge_Mendes "Jorge Mendes") denied the claims, labelling them
"journalistic fiction", with Ronaldo stating it was consensual sex.[520] _Der
Spiegel_ published a further story in response to the denial, alleging that
text messages sent by Ronaldo showed he was aware of the legal negotiations.
According to _Der Spiegel_ , the woman received US$375,000 in the
settlement.[519]

In July 2017, Ronaldo was charged with fraudulently evading almost €15 million
in tax between 2011 and 2014, a claim he denies.[521] In May 2018, Spanish tax
authorities rejected Ronaldo's settlement offer of €14 million.[522] It was
reported on 15 June, just before Spain played Portugal in the 2018 World Cup,
Ronaldo had been sentenced to two years in jail (suspended) and fined €18.8
million after reaching a deal with Spanish authorities. The sentence can be
served under probation, without any jail time, so long as he does not
reoffend.[523] On 15 June 2018, Ronaldo paid $21.7 million in restitution
regarding his past tax frauds in order to avoid jail time.[524] The Spanish
government would later reduce the amount by €2 million.[525]

#### World

  * Most (FIFA) [Ballon d'Or](/wiki/Ballon_d%27Or "Ballon d'Or") awards: 5 (2008, 2013, 2014, 2016, 2017) (shared with [Lionel Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi"))

  5. **Jump up ^** Real Madrid had previously recognized Ronaldo as their all-time top scorer after he scored a brace against [Malmö FF](/wiki/Malm%C3%B6_FF "Malmö FF") on 30 September 2015.
